The strike has been organized by local workers in Catalonia's textile industry. The workers have started demanding better working conditions and a higher wage. Despite our best efforts, the strike has quickly spread and engulfed other industries in the region, presently involving up to 100,000 workers. Our officials in the area have repeatedly tried to break up the strikes and to arrest their leaders, however the strikes have continued for several weeks and have caused significant turmoil in Catalonia.

The merchants and industrialists of Barcelona, enraged by the tax hikes put in place to pay for the expenses of the Spanish–American War, have been led by their mayor into a strike. \nThe strikers have shut down their businesses and industrial establishments, creating a situation in which they are untaxable. The personal and corporate tax rates in Catalonia, higher than even in our capital of Madrid, have created a feeling of betrayal among the Catalan upper and middle classes, who had fought alongside and been largely loyal to Spanish nobility. \nBarcelona lies in a state of emergency, and the strike has spread to neighboring cities in the province.

We have received news of a shocking slaughter of students and workers of the Central University of Madrid, including women, children and the elderly. The act has been perpetrated by units of our military, with the students being brutally attacked whilst performing a serenade in support of their rector, Juan Manuel Montalbán at the Puerta del Sol. Montalbán was deposed 3 days ago by order of our government because of his failure to dismiss Professor Emilio Castelar after his recent publications in the newspaper titled ''La Democracia'', which was critical of Queen Isabel II. The backlash from Juan Manuel Montalbán's dismissal and replacement by a new rector provoked the protesters to act. This afternoon, students and workers came to the Puerta del Sol, being dispersed once more by soldiers indiscriminately firing into the crowd. The attacks were successful in dispersing the protesters, though they left behind around 10 dead and 200 wounded.

The Orthographic Norms, commissioned by the Institute for Catalan Studies, are a list of 24 rules aimed at standardizing written Catalan, which has until now lacked a unified orthography. \nThe commissioners' goal was to bring Catalan up to par with other European languages - to equip writers with the ability to communicate advanced concepts in the language of the people. The rules were swiftly embraced by writers and journalists, paving the way for schools and universities to educate students in the common tongue, and eventually becoming the standard of local business.

The "Normes de Castelló", a set of orthographic rules concerning the Valencian language, have recently been approved and ratified in Castelló de la Plana by prominent cultural and political figures of the Valencian Country. A total of 34 orthographic rules were agreed on to provide a basis for the normification for Valencian spelling. Regarding these orthographic rules, two prominent aspects stand out: Firstly, orthographic model is quite similar to the one used by the primary authors of the Valencian Renaissance, including but not limited to Teodor Llorente Olivares. Secondly, it shares certain structures of the orthographic rules of the Catalan language that were formulated in 1913 by the Institute d'Estudis Catalans. The high conformity with which the new orthographic rules are being implemented is surprising: Practically all Valencian writers, associations and main newspapers are using them without question. With Valencian spelling finally codified and mutually agreed upon, the study and preservation of the language has become easier.

Captain General of the Baelaric Islands, Jaime Ortega y Olleta landed on Sant Carles de la Ràpita with an army of 3000 men from the Baelaric garrison in an effort to trigger a revolt in our forces in Catalonia and force Queen Isabell II to abdicate in favor of the Carlist pretender, Carlos VI. Initially supported by both Carlos and his brother Infante Fernando, as well as the archbishop of Toledo Cirilo de Alameda, the garrison quickly started losing support for the general, as they weren't informed on the reason for their expedition. Eventually the soldiers turned on their general in favor of the queen and the government, forcing the pretenders to flee towards Ulldecona. The traitorous general got captured by our forces 3 days after his landing and sentenced to death by the court martial. The Carlist pretenders, later captured by the Guardia Civil, were given amnesty in exchange for both signing their resignation to the throne of Spain, and were both deported to France.

During a military parade led by General Arsenio Martínez Campos in Barcelona, an assassination attempt unfolded. The general sustained minor injuries, but the attack resulted in sixteen people being seriously wounded, with one of them, a civil guard, dying shortly after. \n\nThe perpetrator, an anarchist named Paulino Pallás, was apprehended and subsequently sentenced to death, with his execution taking place two weeks later. Pallás claimed during the trial that he was seeking revenge for the execution of four anarchists in Jerez de la Frontera the previous year.

The aftermath of the Massacre of St. Daniel's Night was cluttered and confusing. With the dismissal of General Ramón Narváez, Duke of Valencia, from the position of Prime Minister, Gen. Leopoldo O'Donnell formed a Unión Liberal government. Gen. Juan Prim, a leader of the Progressives, attempted to get the Progressives to cease their withdrawal from voting, but was unable to do so. \nWith no other course of action, Prim attempted a pronouncement, attempting to force the Queen to make him the Prime Minister of Spain. Prim attempted to carry out a military-only coup with no civilian assistance, believing that the move would make his success easier. However, due to the preparations of O'Donnell, most military units in Madrid remained loyal to the government. Several units abandoned Prim, and the rest traveled around Castille before fleeing into Portugal without attacking the city of Madrid.

Following the failure of the Pronuncimento of General Prim a year earlier, and the onset of financial maladies in Spain, General Prim continued his work of Progressive agitation in Spain. With the stated objective of overthrowing the Queen, supporters of the coup would designate Ricardo Muñiz as the man responsible for agitating the working classes of Madrid to join the revolt. Among the revolters was Spanish politician and future Prime Minister Práxedes Sagasta. The uprising was planned for the 26th of June, 1866. \nFearful of government anticipation, the revolt occurred 4 days earlier than planned. Artillery units roamed around Madrid, while progressives and democrats fought on barricades and government generals fanned out around the city to ensure the loyalty of the other military units. The rebels attempted to enter the Queen's palace but were stopped by loyal units. The revolt was eventually contained to the barracks by the 23rd and suppressed by the afternoon of the 23rd.

In 1865, the village of El Fener, in the municipality of Escaldes-Engordany, was buried in a landslide. The village was abandoned after the landslide, its inhabitants dispersed. No attempt to reinhabit the land was made until the 20th century.

Recently, the village of El Fener, in the municipality of Escaldes-Engordany, was buried in a landslide. Our Andorran neighbors have thus come to us to ask if we may assist in the reconstruction of the village. However, its reconstruction may be challenging, given that there is not a great demand for the houses to be reconstructed and the original inhabitants may not return.

Huang Yupian, a native of Kansu province, serving as magistrate of Qinghe county in Chihli province, has published a work called 'A Detailed Refutation of Heresy' in which he condemns and debunks elements of the syncretic religious and political movement of Mahayana Buddhists called 'The White Lotus'. It has caused us much trouble in the past, including an uprising in 1874 and an attempted siege of the Forbidden City in 1813. To permanently put an end to the movement, Huang Yupian has banned the 'Precious Scrolls', writings of the White Lotus movement, and established Confucian schools in Mahayana-populated areas to convert Buddhists.

Huang Yupian, a native of Kansu province, serving as magistrate of Qinghe county in Chihli province, has published a work called 'A Detailed Refutation of Heresy' in which he condemns and debunks elements of the syncretic religious and political movement of Mahayana Buddhists called 'The White Lotus'. It has caused us much trouble in the past, including an uprising in 1794 and an attempted siege of the Forbidden City in 1813. To permanently put an end to the movement, Huang Yupian has banned the 'Precious Scrolls', writings of the White Lotus movement, and established Confucian schools in Mahayana-populated areas to convert Buddhists.

The highest mountain in Ecuador, Chimborazo, has been summited by Edward Whymper, a London mountaineer, explorer, illustrator, and author best known for the first ascent of the Matterhorn in 1865. He was accompanied by Italian climbers Louis  and Jean-Antoine Carrel. At 6,263 m, the ascent marks the highest point that European mountaineers have ever reached. While in the 17th and 18th century, the mountain was thought to be the highest point on Earth, we now know of higher peaks in the Himalayas that have not yet been conquered. Edward Whymper also made a collection of amphibians and reptiles that he handed over to George Albert Boulenger at the British Museum which is now on exhibition.
The Abolition of Slavery in the French Colonies

At the instigation of Victor Schoelcher, Under-Secretary of State for the Navy and the Colonies and a firm, steadfast advocate for abolition, the provisional government has issued a decree that proclaims slavery to be an attack on human dignity, that destroys the free will of man and suppresses the natural principle of right and duty, and is therefore a flagrant violation of the republican principals of “Liberté, égalité, fraternité”. As such, the decree states that slavery in all its forms has been abolished in all French colonies and possessions, all French citizens are forbidden from participating in the practice in any regard and all former slaves are granted the status of citizens of France.

The loss of Île de France to The British following the Napoleonic Wars meant that we have lost an important foothold in the Indian Ocean. In need of a replacement for Port-Louis, the Governor of Bourbon Admiral de Hell has planned an expedition to Nosy Be, an island off the northwest coast of Madagascar. The inhabiting Sakalava people are generally involved in the slave trade and should not put up noteworthy resistance.

A French expedition has taken control of Nosy Be just off of our coast. Although a military post so close to our homeland is a direct threat to our sovereignty, with the Merina right outside of our borders we can't risk turning our attention elsewhere.

Ever since our rebellion against the Merina in 1835, we've made numerous unsuccessful attempts to expel them from our kingdom. However, following a betrayal of one of our own, we were forced to retreat all the way to Nosy Mitsio. With our kingdom on the brink of collapse, King Tsimiaro has decided to sail to the French island of Bourbon as a last resort. By personally offering to become a protectorate as well as granting ownership of several of our islands, the French can be persuaded to protect us from further Merina aggression. Submitting to the Europeans may be an unthinkable act, but it's the only way to ensure our people's survival.

A most peculiar guest has arrived before the Governor of the island of Bourbon today: The exiled king of Antankarana. He had barely made it out alive after numerous clashes with the rival Kingdom of Imerina, which is why he is offering us his kingdom's loyalty as well as legal ownership of its northwestern islands in return for military protection to check the Merina advance. The island's terrain makes fighting a grueling task, but gaining a foothold on the island's North and the support of the locals makes this a worthwhile task.

France is suffering from an economic depression and widespread unemployment. This was beneficial in causing the unrest that dethroned our previous king, but it also makes our new position precarious. While the revolutionaries were united against the monarchy, cracks are beginning to form. Louis Jean Joseph Blanc, a radical member of the provisional government, has proposed the creation of so-called "national workshops", where the unemployed are offered work at government-run sites. There, they may perform unskilled labor at a low wage for the common good, such as construction of new housing or roads. While such a program would unquestionably be quite costly, if we don't take action to assist the unemployed, dissatisfied §Rradical Parisians may overthrow the provisional government§! and expel the moderates. We have little choice in the matter.
The National Workshops are an institution used by the Provisional Government to provide employment to the masses affected by the economic depression.

After months of discussion among members of the provisional government concerning the future French political system, a compromise has been reached. While the revolution was at first quite radical, more moderate and even conservative elements of the population have increased their influence to the extent that the extremists have been outweighed significantly. The new constitution re-affirms the provisional government's policy of universal suffrage. Instead of the right to work, which is strongly desired by the left, the constitution simply grants the unemployed a "right to assistance". Propositions such as the separation of church and state, banning members of the Bonaparte family from running for office and abolishing the death penalty are rejected by the conservatives and thus not included in the constitution.

Unemployed Parisians, disillusioned after the revolution failed to improve their situation, have taken up arms against the provisional government. Egged on by radical politicians like Louis Blanc, these radicals stormed the government buildings in Paris, arresting and in some cases lynching the ministers of the provisional government. Peasant leaders have formed a new ruling council, organizing the new second revolution and taking control of the administration. With supporters ousting bourgeois officials across France, new reforms have already been successfully instituted with much speed to alleviate the situation of the peasants. It would seem that the new government is here to stay - much to the displeasure of the European monarchies.

Ulysse Trélat, a moderate member of the provisional government has, with the support of conservative figures outside of government, demanded the end of the National Workshops. The streets of Paris have been re-paved, and the situation of the populace has been somewhat alleviated. They argue that the cost of employing over a hundred thousand people is at this point not worth the results and must therefore be ended. While the radicals in government protest Trélat's demand, it seems that most of France agrees with his sentiment.

Angered by the abrogation of the National Workshop program, Parisians who are now once again unemployed and without government support have taken to the streets in an attempt to overthrow the provisional government. The city was divided into two camps, with the dividing line running from Montmartre in the Northeast down to the Porte Saint-Denis, across the Île de la Cité and, skirting the rue Saint-Jacques, to the city limits. Archbishop Denys Auguste Affre of Paris attempted to broker a ceasefire by stepping between national guardsmen and the rebels only to be killed by a stray bullet. After several days of bitter fighting, the last barricade in the district of Faubourg Saint-Antoine fell to the National Guard, ending the insurrection. Around 5000 rebels died, and several thousand more were taken captive and are being deported to French Algeria.

The Madagascarian aristocracy refused to accept the abolition of slavery in France, uniting under Bahotsivintsy, the leader of a tribal coalition of Sakalava people. The French then were confined to the city of Hell-Ville after the island was quickly overrun by rebels. An army of 4,000 Malagasy descended on the city of Hell-Ville, after burning the port of Ambanoro. French artillery was able to repel the assault and drive back the Sakalava army with heavy losses. \nFollowing the arrival of French reinforcements from Mayotte, the French launched a brutal response into the interior, looting crops, burning canoes, ransacking villages, and pacifying the countryside. All the slaveowners that remained through the revolt and did not defect were compensated, while the rest of the revolting aristocrats received nothing.

While on a training exercise for Prussian warships, Prince Adalbert decided to explore the Rif coast of Morocco, manning two boats and deploying them along the coast. After the boats came under fire from the Moroccans, the SMS Danzig moved to only 600m from the shore to give the boat crews supporting fire. Adalbert then ordered a landing operation led by him personally. This attack was successful and the Moroccans were forced back to a plateau. However, they were also receiving continuous reinforcements and so Adalbert finally decided to withdraw, in case he and his troops were cut off from the shore. Prussian casualties were seven dead and 22 wounded, including Adalbert, shot in the thigh. Despite this failure, the courage of Adalbert and his sailors received high praise from the Prussian people.

The island of Nias is almost completely isolated thanks to its distance from mainland Sumatra. However, the activities of its people were recorded by the Kingdom of Barus, of which the island was officially part since at least the tenth century. In 1672, the Dutch East India Company was granted permission by the kingdom to carry out trade on Nias. Now, the Nias Expedition has been launched in order to grow spices on the island and build harbors on the coast, as well as to make it easier for us to control the trade routes on the west cost of Sumatra.

Si Musa, the powerful and extremely wealthy Grand Vizier of Morocco, wishes to construct a palace as a personal residence befitting his status in Marrakesh. He plans to bring in the most skilled artisans and materials from all across the land to construct a truly opulent palace, which will include a vast riad garden, that will be the largest, most imposing and most sumptuous in all Morocco! §RConstruction will end in 5 years, and give you research point and prestige buffs.§W

The Bahia Palace, the largest and most luxurious of its kind in the whole country, has finally been completed! Initially begun by Grand Vizier Si Musa, it was greatly expanded by his son Ba Ahmed after he succeeded his father. The palace now covers a total area of around 8 hectares, with 150 rooms, a number of smaller courtyards and riad gardens to complement the Grand Riad built by Si Musa and its most notable feature, the opulent decorations, which include walls featuring stucco carved with Arabic inscriptions, geometric patterns, arabesques, and muqarnas, floors paved with marble and zellij tiles and cedar-wood ceilings painted with colorful floral patterns, along with the carved and painted wooden canopies of major doorways.

Shocking news! The imperial train, carrying the royal family including the Tsar himself, was en-route from Crimea to Saint Petersburg when it suddenly derailed at high speed near Borki. Twenty one people were killed instantly. However, the Tsar was able to protect his family by holding up the roof of the dining car when it collapsed, allowing the children to escape and sparing them all from injury. The miraculous salvation of the royal family has been hailed as divine intervention, sourced from the divine power of worship from Moscow. Icons depicting the occasion have been widely distributed amongst the people, and a number of churches around the area have been commissioned to commemorate this miracle. Blame for the accident has largely been laid at the feet of the late Jewish rail baron Samuel Polyakov by the public, who was deemed responsible for the substandard, too thin gravel ballast pads that failed to cushion track vibrations as they were supposed to.

Our Principal Minister, Chakir Saheb Ettabaâ, has proposed transforming the informal school in the Bardo palace for the Mamluks who trained the royal guards of the Bey into a true military school, as part of plans to reform the Tunisian army to compete with the military superiority of the Christian West. The school will have European instructors and will train the sons of former dignitaries of the Turkish militia of Tunis into becoming the future of the Tunisian army.

The Bardo Military School allows us to train our future officers in the latest ways of war and study the latest war technology. However, attracting and retaining the school’s European instructors comes at a significant cost to the treasury…
Despite our prior decision to continue maintaining the Bardo Military School, we must come to realize its immense costs. If our economy is to recover, we must make a sacrifice.

With the financial situation of the Beylik worsening, and with pressure from European creditors mounting, our Grand Vizier and Minister of Finance Mustapha Khaznadar has proposed closing the Bardo Military School. While the school is a significant drain on our treasury, some argue that the military benefits of the school are far too important to lose, especially with the Europeans looking to prey upon our small state. What should we do?

Terrible news from New Orleans! This afternoon, black supporters, including 200 Civil War veterans, of the Louisiana State Constitutional Convention, which authorized greater civil freedoms to blacks within Louisiana, launched a parade to the Mechanics Institute to show their support for the convention. However, on the corner of Common and Dryades streets, across from the Mechanics Institute, a group of armed whites awaited the black marchers. This group was composed largely of Democrats who opposed abolition, most of whom were ex-Confederates. It is not known which group fired first, but within minutes, there was a battle in the streets. The black marchers were unprepared and mostly unarmed
French: they rapidly dispersed, with many seeking refuge within the Mechanics Institute. Nearly 200 people were killed, almost all of them African Americans.

English: On Monday, approximately 4,000 Chartist sympathizers, under the leadership of John Frost, marched on the town of Newport in Wales. En route, some Newport chartists were arrested by police and held prisoner at the Westgate Hotel in central Newport. Chartists from industrial towns outside of Newport, including many coal miners, some with homemade arms, were intent on liberating their fellow Chartists. Fighting began, and soldiers of the 45th Regiment of Foot, deployed in the protection of the police, were ordered to open fire. About 10-24 Chartists were confirmed killed, whilst reports of perhaps a further 50 injured. The three leaders of the rising have been arrested for high treason and sentenced to be hung, drawn and quartered. However, we are being directly lobbied by the Lord Chief Justice to commute the sentence to transportation. What should we do?

The Supreme Ruthenian Council is a political organization created in Lemberg in response to the creation of the Polish Central National Council, which had claimed itself to be the representative body of the Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria. Its goals are the division of Galicia into two separate administrative units: western for Poles and eastern for Ukrainians, the unity of all Ukrainian lands into one province and having lectures in schools and the publishing of government statements conducted in Ukrainian. It has also proclaimed the national flag of the Ruthenian land to be the Ruthenian lion on the colors of yellow and blue.

Shocking news! While parading in his carriage with his daughter, Emperor Wilhelm I was fired upon by an anarchist later identified as Emil Max Hödel, a plumber from Leipzig who had once been a member of the Socialist Workers Party of Germany. Fortunately, all of the shots fired missed the Emperor and injured no one else. The assailant was immediately seized by police, and will certainly soon be executed for his treason.

With the recent radical attacks on the life of the Emperor, it has become readily apparent that the insidious socialist forces within the Empire, such as the SPD, that inspired these attacks must be curtailed. The proposed law will ban any group or meeting whose aims are to spread social-democratic principles, outlaw trade unions, close several socialist newspapers and ban the display of socialist emblems, and will remain in force for 2 and a half years unless extended.

A British merchant named Matthew Isaac Wilson has offered to sell the CSS Shenandoah, a former Confederate commerce raider that was sold to him by the United States after the fall of the Confederacy, to our Sultan. Before its surrender, the ship was one of the most fierce and feared raiders in the Confederate navy, sinking or bonding 38 merchant vessels in the span of 12 and a half months as part of the Confederate effort to disrupt the Union’s economy. This could prove a very valuable addition to our burgeoning state. How should the Sultan respond?

Terrible news! A storm has struck the shores of Zanzibar and wrecked all the docked ships. Many of our plantations are damaged, and it will take a long time to repair them. Hundreds have died due to drowning in sinking ships, being overwhelmed by flooding or being trapped in collapsing buildings. Not only it will cost a lot of money to rebuild the Royal Navy, but our grip on East Africa is also severely weakened by this blow to our military and economy.

Lieutenant Louis Édouard Bouët-Willaumez was recently sent to the coast of central Africa aboard the steamer l'Africain to patrol and catch slave brigs, enforcing the ban on the slave trade. He has returned, bearing news of successful treaties of protection with local Mpongwe rulers Antchuwè Kowè Rapontchombo and Anguilè Ré-Dowé. This places the coast between Cape Esterias and Cape Lopez firmly under our influence. Perhaps this will lead to a future colonial venture?

Today is a great day! The young prince Ahmad ibn Mustafa has taken the throne today in a grand ceremony fit for a king. After the death of his beloved father, Mustafa ibn Mahmud, Ahmad I has taken over responsibility for ruling the country. He has many ambitions to modernize Tunisia, secure its position and assert our power. May our Tunis grow and prosper under the guidance of our bey!

The British consul general, Thomas Reade, has just met with Ahmed Bey. He strongly advised the abolition of slavery in Tunisia for two reasons. Firstly, he claims that the practice is inhumane and must be brought to an end for the sake of morality. Secondly, he warns that a colonial power could use the presence of captured white slaves as a pretext to invade us. Ahmed Bey, himself the son of a slave woman, is sympathetic to Reade's arguments. How shall we proceed?

Following the freedom of womb instated 4 years ago by Ahmed Bey, he has voiced his intention to finally put an end to slavery altogether. Giuseppe Raffo, a dignitary of Italian origin currently serving as our foreign minister, has drafted a decree that would abolish slavery in any way, shape and form on the territory of the Beylik of Tunisia. Has the time come to grant freedom to over a hundred thousand people?

Ahmed I, Bey of Tunis, is a man with aspirations for a modernized Tunisia. The former navy, the legacy of the corsairs, was struck down in Greece at the battle of Navarino, in 1827. Ahmed has already taken great steps to rebuild Tunisian naval forces and secure the existence of a modernized army, and he has taken similar steps to modernize the naval forces. In 1841, Tunisia bought its first steamship, which sunk a year later, and was replaced. Italian and French naval advisors roam throughout the coastal regions, scouting out natural harbors and potential naval bases for the Bey's consideration, while the harbors at La Marsa are modernized. Year after year, the trappings of the West pierce closer into the Beylik.

Our consul general to Tunis, Thomas Reade, recently became aware of an ancient Lybico-Punic mausoleum located in Dougga dated to the 2nd Century BCE. Recognizing the importance of the bilingual inscription on the mausoleum's interior in decoding the ancient Libyan language, Reade extracted it from the monument and had it dispatched to London for the 'benefit of science', where it now resides in the British Museum. Regrettably, the removal process involved taking the entire wall of stone blocks on which it was inscribed, resulting in the collapse of the two upper floors that had stood for over 1600 years.

Our land, our land, our Fatherland! Ring out, dear word, oh sound! No rising hill, or mountain grand, no sloping dale, no northern strand, there is, more loved, to be found, Than this — our fathers' ground.\n\nOn this day, Swedish-Finnish poet Johan Ludvig Runeberg published his patriotic hymn "Vårt land," or "Maamme" in Finnish--meaning "Our Land." The song forms the prologue of Runeberg's epic The Tales of Ensign Stål, which tells of Sweden's loss of Finland to the Russian Empire in the 1808 Finnish War. The hymn, despite being originally written in Swedish, forms a basis for a reawakening of Finnish national pride. Perhaps this heralds a new era of nationalism for the Finnish people.

Coringa was a city full of life and riches. It welcomed thousands of ships every year and was an important trade center in Bay of Bengal, until today. A terrifying cyclone of magnitude the locals have never seen before ravaged the city, killing hundreds of thousands of people, and razed the port. While Coringa was no stranger to cyclones, this one made sure that most of the survivors would leave the city to her fate. The city was abandoned by the local population and the officials.

In the Sierra Nevada range of California, a group of three determined climbers achieved a monumental feat - the first ascent of Mount Whitney, the tallest mountain in the contiguous United States. The climb was arduous and fraught with difficulty, as the team encountered steep snowfields and treacherous rocky terrain. Altitude sickness plagued the climbers, causing them to feel dizzy and short of breath as they approached the summit. But they persevered, pushing themselves to their limits, and eventually, after many hours of grueling ascent, they stood atop the mountain, with its breathtaking views stretching out before them. To commemorate their historic achievement, the team placed a wooden stake at the summit, bearing their names and the date of their successful ascent. Marking the beginning of a new era of mountaineering, with Mount Whitney becoming a sought-after destination for adventurers from around the world.

As the Hungarian Revolution engulfs the land, Romanian loyalists to Austria have taken up arms and begun indiscriminate slaughter of civilians in Transylvania. Incited by local leaders, militiamen wander through villages and mark their inhabitants for death. Large killings occurred in Kisenyed and Nagyenyed, where up to 175 and 1,000 people were killed respectively. The massacres primarily target Hungarians, though Romanians, Germans, and Jews have also fallen victim.\n\nRomanian lawyer Avram Iancu played a role in organizing the militias responsible for the massacres. Troops under his control also engaged the Hungarian army, though their resistance is overshadowed by the wanton destruction they have caused.
The cycle of bloodshed perpetuates itself.

A series of uprisings by disaffected workers have occurred in Barcelona, in which textile factory laborers have broken into their workplaces and destroyed the spinning mules inside. The particular machine targeted in these uprisings, the selfactina--whose name is derived from the term "self-acting machine"--provoked the workers' ire because of it requiring far fewer workers to operate it while spinning far more strings than other machines. This development has led to massive unemployment in Barcelona's textile industry.\n\nThe riots continue to rage on. In one incident, rioters broke into a factory, destroyed all of its selfactinas, and murdered the owner, his son, and the foreman. The Barcelona government-general is deliberating a ban of selfactinas in response, but their manufacturers would surely plea to Madrid to repeal such an effort.

Today, our capital has fallen to the Toucouleur armies of Omar Tall in a quick and inevitable war. Our rulers in the borderlands haven't resisted their invasion, and they have entered unoposed our core territories. We must now join the Jihad if we want to survive, or exile to Segu. Though, with the cities of the central deserts under our control, we could form an empire that's able to resist the coming onslaught of the colonial powers.

Today, our border has been struck with an attack by the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ armies of Omar Tall in a quick battle. Our rulers in the borderlands haven't resisted their invasion, and they have entered unoposed our core territories. We must exile to the desert if we want to keep our independence, as they have nothing to win by chasing us to the sands of the Sahara...

Force another §Ycountry§W to concede in Algeria
A new newspaper has entered print, the Petit Parisien. Already immensely popular, it is set to become the most read in France. It is a strong force in advocacy for our republican principles.

§RGain 3 infamy§! The days of paganism are over! We must pursue a policy of conquest to any kingdom which isn't Sunni in our region to bring about the dominance of Islam. We now will conquer Ségou and raze it to the ground for it to become the new Muslim stronghold of the West!

§RGain 1 infamy§! The Kayor Kingdom of Lat Dior controls the coast between Dakar and Saint Louis, rendering impossible any land connection between them. With the fall of the local monarchies feeling imminent, Lat Dior is no longer powerful to efficiently control its territory, and so we could invade and take it without fierce resistance upon our fire arms. What are we waiting for, then? Let the colonization begin! \n\n§RWarning: You have to merge the brigades that are generated by this decision§W

§GLose 1 infamy§! Our country's shape is war itself. We have warred against the Moroccans, the Sahrawis, the Fula and the Wolof, including our neighbor to the South, Waalo. With its ups and downs, we've almost always had a bad relationship, but one thing other than Islam unites us both -- the Senegal River and its natural resources. Being coveted by the French from Saint Louis, we must seek an unbreakable alliance with our Waalo brothers, one to end the invaders at once!

§RGain 4 infamy§! The Plan of 1854 is a plan by the governor of French Senegal Louis Faidherbe which has been put forth in two petitions addressed to Protet signed by the major wholesalers, merchants, and other notables of Saint-Louis, the first in December 1851 and the second in $MONTH$ $YEAR$. This plan calls for us, based in small enclaves on the Atlantic coast at Saint-Louis and at a few other posts along the Senegal River, to become the dominant power in the area rather than one among many, wresting control of the terms and conditions of trade between the French wholesalers and the African producers of exportable agricultural products as acacia gum. The plan calls for the French to fortify more points along the Senegal River to make use of force to end the system of tolls by which the Trarzas profit greatly. It also calls for the French to protect the agricultural population of the left bank of the Senegal River from raids by the Mauritanians and from the possible absorbtion of the Wolof state of Waalo, to Trarza.

The days of paganism are over! We must pursue a policy of conquest to any kingdom which isn't Sunni in our region to bring about the dominance of Islam. We now will conquer Gabu and raze it to the ground for it to become the new Muslim stronghold of the West! \n§GYou need 30% civilization progress to click this decision§W
Help Kanem Rule the Kanem-Bornu Empire

The Kanem-Bornu Empire is in disarray. The mai, the ruler which dynasty has reigned for hundreds of years, is being slowly deposed by the Kanemis, a family which raised to power thanks to their defense against the Sokoto jihad some years ago. All of Bornu is now under their control, and the mai has tried to assassinate him for now more than 10 years, all of them in vain. We must help the mai regain its power and recreate its once prestigious empire! If we don't succeed in the war though, we could try to annex Kanem to put them "under our protection". \n§GYou need 25% civilization progress to click this decision§W

The Kanem-Bornu Empire is in disarray. The mai, the ruler which dynasty has reigned for hundreds of years, is being slowly deposed by the Kanemis, a family which raised to power thanks to their defense against the Sokoto jihad some years ago. All of Bornu is now under Kanemi's control, and the mai has tried to assassinate him for now more than 10 years, all of them in vain. Waddai and its ruler, Muhammad Sharif, have helped Kanem in a new move to overthrow al-Kanemi, through launching war on us and siezing our capital.

Our influence in the region of Grand Guinea has growed in the last years, most notably in the Pongo and Nuñez rivers, where we've signed numerous treaties of trade and protection. It might be time to capitalize on the treaties and take over the Rivières du Sud.

Our empire is now one of the greatest empires that have ever been formed in the South of West Africa, and it can now only grow more. With the Europeans approaching from every direction, it might be time to capitalize on the decline of the kingdoms of the East and grow our empire enough so it is a power to reckon.

As Bitòn Coulibaly tightened his control over Ségou, capital of his newly founded Segu Empire, a faction of Ségou Bambara dissatisfied with his rule fled west. In 1753, they founded the kingdom of Kaarta on the homeland of the long-defunct Ghana Empire, taking Nioro as their capital. Kaarta then was and will be Segu!

Al-Kuti was founded in the late 1820s by a local ruler of Waddai, whom settled in the south of the kingdom after a search for slaves and granted the zone to Waddai vassaldom. It's possible that the Emirate is now obsolete, as we can now take it over.

The Kanem-Bornu Empire has always been an empire with a sphere of influence. Hundreds of kings and emirs in our borderlands claim allegiance to our empire, and multiple wars have been caused by the system, most notably the War of Katagum. With the newly gained European weapons, we can now efficiently keep our sphere of influence more tightly controlled and take them over eventually.

The Sokoto Jihad has now been raging on for decades, and the Fulani have brought destruction (and Islam) to every corner of our region. With their newly found weakness, we can now take them over and install a new Empire, one that won't discriminate on religion or identity. One that won't exploit the Hausa people.

The Mossi haven't been united for now centuries, and Yenenga's great Mossi Empire is now a distant memory. The legend says the princess Yennenga escaped dressed as a man when she came to the house of a Mandé elephant hunter named Rialé. They had a son named Wédrago who was given that name from the horse that Yennenga used to escape. Wédrago visited his grandfather in Dagomba at the age of fifteen and was given four horses, 50 cows, and a number of Dagomba horseman joined his forces. With these forces, Wédrago conquered the local people, married a woman named Puiriketa who gave him three sons, and built the city of Tenkodogo. The oldest was Diaba Lompo who founded the city of Fada Ngourma. The second son, Rawa, became the ruler of Jatenga. His third son, Zungrana became the ruler in Tenkodogo after Wédrago died. Zungrana married Pouitenga, a woman sent from the king of the Ninisi people, and the resulting intermarriage between the Dagomba, the Mande, the Ninisi, and local peoples became the Mossi people. We must recreate the legend and unite the kingdoms that divide our great people!
Support Muhammad al-Sharif's claim to Wadai

Wadai has been in a power struggle with claimant to the throne Muhammad al-Sharif for the past 3 years, and their army has faced unending battles with thousands of casualties. If we support al-Sharif, who was born in Darfur, we may acquire great influence on the Kingdom of Wadai, which is the key to lucrative trade routes to Tripoli. We would be able to extract tribute from the kingdom by permanently installing al-Sharif as our vassal.

Thanks to our support, we have acquired great influence on the Kingdom of Wadai, which is the key to lucrative trade routes to Tripoli. Sharif, though, isn't known for establishing long-lasting alliances, so we might be intervening in Waddai soon enough.

Muhammad Sharif has refused to pay this year's tribute, and is reforming the military to stand against us. Sharif wasn't known for establishing long-lasting alliances, and as we expected we might want to intervene again.

Our beloved Kolak, Muhammad Abd al-Aziz Dhawiyi ibn Radama, has died after a six-year reign. With Adham ibn Muhammad Abd al-Aziz, his young son, ascending the throne, Wadai has been thrown into chaos. The young Kolak, not yet of age, has been challenged by several would-be usurpers, chief among them Muhammad al-Sharif. He has begun leading a revolt in a bid for the throne, receiving support from the dastardly Sultanate of Darfur. While the uprising is currently small in scale, once Darfur fully commits its forces to the conflict, there is little chance for Adham ibn Muhammad Abd al-Aziz to remain Kolak. For now, all we can do is bide our time.

Our Kolak is currently Muhammad al-Sharif, a warlord originating in Darfur that has taken the throne of Wadai thanks to his knowledge of guerrilla warfare and support granted by the Sultanate of Darfur. Using his extensive knowledge of warfare, our Kolak has launched reforms to modernize the army of Wadai with the goal guiding us towards a brighter future as a regional power.

The Fur aren't an united people, and their rulers are weak and pathetic. Though the Sultanate helped Muhammad al-Sharif take the throne of Wadai, we owe them nothing. Being subjugated by Darfur doesn't benefit us, and with our military power they can do little to prevent us from achieving our independence.

The once powerful Songhai Empire was shattered by the Moroccans coming from the other side of the Sahara, armed with guns we now can access. With the decadence of Morocco, their influence in the Niger river has also diminished, and their control is now minimal. The flag of the Songhai flows once again over Gao, and no one can stop our dream of an empire!

The Songhai are weak, and their people are pagan. They are the only people that separate us from the great Sokoto Empire, and we must join forces to expulse the Dendi to Songhailand where they belong, and bring Islam once and for all to the region. We hope Sokoto will help us, or winning the war will be hard, as the Dendi cavalry still remember the days of the Songhai Empire, and their tactics still aren't outdated, regardless of guns.

Liptako has started a Jihad against the reminders of the Songhai Empire, and in return of our help would let itself become our tributary. The Songhai are weak, and their people are pagan. They are the only people that separate us from Liptako, and we must join forces to expulse the Dendi to Songhailand where they belong, and bring Islam once and for all to the region.

The Songhai are weak, and their people are pagan. We must join forces with Liptako to expulse the Dendi to Songhailand where they belong, and bring Islam once and for all to the region. Liptako will be launching it first but with our support, or winning the war would be hard for them, as the Dendi cavalry still remember the days of the Songhai Empire, and their tactics still aren't outdated, regardless of guns.

Abu Arish was a kingdom under our influence in the region of the Taiz coast. When we were fighting the Egyptians, the Zaydis took it over, and came closer to Mecca. We must expulse them from the region and bring them under our thumb! §RDue to engine limitations, you will annex the lands of Abu Arish with a status quo Casus Belli, and the Zaydis will have a Casus Belli to get it back.§W

Despite centuries of European domination of the coast of Angola, the colony's far-flung and vast interior has long eluded our grasp. With growing interest in the territory and recent advances in medicine combatting the endemic diseases, we should consider begin extending our rule eastward.
The interior of Angola has been granted to us by the Great Powers, and we now may take it without international complaints -- it is $COUNTRY_ADJ$ territory!

The Lunda Empire, once powerful, is now in decadence. European intervention and the introduction of guns has made its wars more deadly than ever. We are the only state in the region aside from the Great Lakes states that conserve an army capable of conquest, and we could use it to take over Lunda. We once were one of the forming cultures of the Empire, with Chokwes benefiting of the empire, but with its decadence only we can keep intact the greatness of our people!

European intervention and the introduction of guns has made its wars more deadly than ever. We are one of the only states in the region that conserve an army capable of conquest, but the Chokwe have started a war of conquest regardless.

The Mutapa Empire once spanned all of the Shona peoples, from the coast of Sofala to the highland at the frontier with the Tswana. If we become again the strongest Shona state, we can take the title of the Monomutapa!

The Luvale are a mixture of the Lozi, Lunda, Mbundu and Chokwe peoples, and once belonged to our Barotse state. For these reasons, Luvale will always and has always been an integral part of our kingdom.

The Massangano are a series of kingdoms of partial Portuguese descent that are on the banks of the Zambezi river, from Inhambina to Vila de Sena. Some of them are really powerful, and hold great armies, but claim partial allegiance to our state. If we want to keep our expansion in the region, we must take the Massangano and expand on the Zambezi river. Onwards!
The Matakenya currently own Songo, which is at the end of the land we oficially claim for ourselves in the Zambezi River. We need to take such city so we can effectively occupy our claims.

The Berber and Bedouin tribes of the interior claim allegiance to our kingdom, but they keep rebelling and being a weakness to our state. The Europeans use this weakness to attack us, and we must end it via exerting real control over our territory. Centralizing will be a costly and slow process, but it will be worth it.\n\n§RYou need at least 55% civilization progress, the tooltip lies.§W

The Berber and Bedouin tribes of Tarfaya don't claim allegiance to our kingdom, but their northern lands keep rebelling and being a weakness to their state. We must expand to the Draa river and take Guelmim, to find our natural border between the semideserts of Bujadur and the Sahara to the South, and the Atlas Mountains.

The last step to centralize our kingdom is here. The Berber and Bedouins finally are under our state, and Moroccan flags wave over the desert. We have finally centralized Morocco, and brought prosperity to our people. We are now a power to take into account, and colonizing us will be impossible thanks to our great army.

A Mandinka king by the name of Vakaba Toure is fielding troops at Kulukoro, a region between us and the Baté, with the goal of overthrowing our kingdom. In 1845, he with his cousin Vasanissi went to defend maternal relatives in Kulukoro against Cisse, Vanassi killed Cisse in an ambush and the cousins convinced his army to support them in an attack against us. We must move fast or we will end up dead.

We once were part of the Kong Empire, but its dependence on the slave trade made them weak enough for them to leave Bobo Dioulasso without any way to retaliate. They have been trying to take us over with raids since, but have been unsuccessful. With our kingdom not being in the best conditions, they are trying again - but this time it isn't just raids, but their entire army.
With the war at Liptako, our state has changed. Being a part of Sokoto might end up marking our downfall, and independence is tempting. We must hold our breath under the sun of Allah.

Our state has survived everything under the sun -- the Sokoto Jihad, the Kanem-Bornu, the Adamawa, the coastal confederations... the list is almost infinite. Over our greatness, though, is our weakness, and the Jukun have grown tired of our state. The Jukun have united under Zikenyu Tsokwa Tasefu, and a town after another have fallen without a battle. The Chamba people, expulsed by the Fulani, are going down the Benue, and instead of allying with us, they have united with Zikenyu Tsokwa Tasefu's forces to bring us down, on the condition of letting them settle on our territory. Our end is as near as this night, or maybe the next, might be the last one.

Parts of the Zanzibari coast have been ruled by our state for years, but as we expand, the peoples that ruled over these areas have united into a confederation, one which wants to take back the Coast of Zanzibar, and be ruled independently from us.

Sharif al-Barak ibn 'Abil's Beihan is as powerful as it has been at any point in history. Our plains are fertile, and our power extends to the coast. We hope our kingdom never sinks under the sand of the unending desert.

Farah Guled, the second Grand Sultan of Isaaq, who lead our forces to victory against the British in the 1827 Battle of Berbera, has passed away. Now, his son, Hassan Farah, has succeeded him as Grand Sultan. The ancient port of Berbera has, in recent years, been fought over between the Ayal Ahmed and Ayal Yunis branches of the Habr Awal clan. As one of his first acts as Grand Sultan, Hassan Farah has brought the warring subclans before a holy relic from the tomb of Aw Barkhadle, one of the companions of the prophet Muhammad, and made them swear to bury all animosity and live as brethren. Thus, Hassan Farah has once again brought peace and good fortune to the Sultanate of Isaaq. May it prosper forevermore!

Our power is becoming our weakness. Our state has in its borders a trade route which brings guns and other European goods to the center of the continent, and all products are taxed if they pass through us. The Portuguese, though, are trying to centralize their dominions in Africa, and our trade routes might become a target which we can't get rid of. Under this new sun, we hope we shall prevail.

Oral tradition holds that we probably settled along the rainy, hot, and humid river valleys of northern and western Congo in the early centuries of the 1st millennium. We suffered during the active slave capture, trade, and export in the 18th and 19th centuries, where "thousands of Mongo people as captured slaves passed through the Zanzibar route by the Arabs". We must survive in this newfound world of greatness and weakness.

Our kingdom is between the prosperous Zulu and the warring Xhosa, with our neighboring British nearing in. Our place in the region, though, grants us the control of the trade routes, and we're slowly becoming a truly powerful kingdom, one to not be left behind in history.

Our people are settled in the wetlands of Mombasa, and our state is between the prosperous Zanzibar and the warring Unyanyembe and Maasai, making us always be under threat. With the Omani and the Europeans encroaching on the coasts, and the Tanzanian kingdoms preparing for a battle to behold, we can only hope our future isn't sentenced.

Our sultanate can now only grow more powerful. Our connections with the Omani and the kingdoms of the interior make us an integral part of the region, and Ujiji is full of traders from all corners of the region. All goods to be ever owned pass through our state, and our land is fertile. We hope our greatness is unending and our future bright!

We have survived. Our sultanate has reunited in the face of the Omani, and the Swahili won't be taken as easily as the Arabs think. Our army grows strong, and our navy prepares for battle. The Omani shall be defeated and the greatness of the Kilwa Sultanate restored!

Our kingdom is between the always-falling Baguirmi and the powerful Kanem-Bornu Empire. Our sphere of influence is nothing compared to Bornu's, and we are de facto their tributary. We must though keep this status or our sovereignty might fall under Bornu, Waddai or even the Adamawa. Our region's future is uncertain, and we must keep all our numbers.

al-Hadj Umar Tall's jihad has arrived to Kaarta, with 50 thousand men and French guns, putting Nioro into a quick siege. We hope our great army continues the jihad and brings Islam to all corners of the Sudan!

Our rapid expansion has led to several skirmishes with the French army. With the authorization of his ally, Khasso Queen Hawa Demba Diallo, Governor Faidherbe ordered a fort built at the Khasso village of Medina, not far from Kayes, in 1855. In late April 1857, our entire army marched on Medina, and started a 3-month-long siege. Fort Medina's garrison consisted in the fort's commander Paul Holle, seven French soldiers, 22 Senegalese Tirailleurs and 34 sailors from Saint-Louis. The siege was lifted some days ago after the fort, with European guns and massive arming of the population, had survived 3 months under full siege. Governor Faidherbe arrived with 500 men after the Senegal river's flow increased thanks to massive rains in the highlands, and our hope to take Kayes and unite with Futa Tooro has been shattered. We though have signed a treaty with the French which lets us annex the interior without French intervention.

Our army, well trained, regimented, and equipped with modern firearms, is the best in the region, and so the Segu can't efficiently resist a conquest of their empire, which is already shaken by rebellions and raids by neighboring Fula states. We shall annex the Bambara Empire and become the biggest empire in the region, bringing Islam to every corner of the region.

With Segu secured, we can now launch an attack on Massina, a fellow jihad state. The Massina though don't have the power to bring jihad effectively to the region, so they deserve annexation so they can be part of a powerful Jihad state, one which isn't eclipsed by Sokoto, or any Pagan state in the region. We must enter Hamdullahi and raze it to the ground!

The French have lost, and our coast will keep being ours, with no intervention from any European power. Now that we've won, though, what should we do with the French railroad? Having French infrastructure might lead us into problems we don't want to deal with, but it could also help us westernize.

'Today we are invaded by the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$. Our army is in disarray. The tiedos of the $COUNTRY_ADJ$, however valiant warriors, have almost all fallen under the enemy's bullets. The $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ are stronger than us, I know that, but should we leave the $COUNTRY_ADJ$ in the hands of the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$?' \nThe $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ have started building forts on the banks of the Senegal river, and attacking from there the neighboring kingdoms. Our sovereignty is being contested, and we might not live to see the sun once again.
Our kingdom is in decadence, and frequent raids weaken us every year. A man called Samori Turé has created a powerful empire inside our territory, and joining it is the only way to survive.
We have been raided for decades by the Bobo Kingdom of Gwiriko, and we now search for revenge. We should end them as a threat by annexing their capital into our state, leaving them as a rump state.

We have been raided for decades by the Senufo Kingdom of Kenedugu. With the Senufo increasingly encroaching into our territory, they have finally shown their true intentions - they want to end our kingdom's existance. This threat can only be an unifying factor in our current situation.

With the slave trade reviving, the search for new slaves has brought the Sahel states to push southwards to previously pagan regions and jungles. With the trade reviving, the states of the Sahel are regaining strength and wielding armies to bring conquest to its neighbors.

The region of Taka, mostly inhabited by nomadic Beja tribesmen, escaped the attentions of the initial 1820 invasion of Sudan, for Sennar was the goal and they did not deviate from the direct route along the Nile. An expedition to the east was indeed suggested to Ismail Pasha, but the Beja had a warlike reputation in Egypt and he decided against it. While Taka paid tribute after the conquest of the Funj Sultanate, this ceased during Khurshid Pasha's term as governor of Sudan in 1838. This prompted the new governor, Ahmad Pasha, to set out with a small army to take control of Taka. When he confronted Sheikh Mohammed Din of the Hadendoa tribe and demanded tribute, he merely produced one tenth of what he had surrendered to Khurshid Pasha. This has enraged Ahmad Pasha, who has now asked us for our blessing to conduct a punitive expedition and found a new fort in the region to collect tribute.

The Mazrui have ruled Mombasa  for now a century and a half, having used the Portuguese's occupation of Zanzibar to build a base of power. They then annexed Malindi and territories near Pate, and the island of Pemba. In 1823 we managed to expulse them from Pate and take Pemba, but they still hold considerable power. Should we send them an ultimatum to end their rebellious existance once and for all?

The Omanis have tried time and time again to end our rule over Mombasa and the surrounding coastal towns for over a century, but since 1823 they have had enough victories to render us weaker than them. They have sent us an ultimatum - cede the remaining lands administered from Mombasa and Mombasa itself, or war will be upon us.
The Subjugation of the Southern Hadendowa

The Hadendowa, a clan of the southern Beja, have increasingly come under our influence. After the founding of Kassala in 1840, the Hadendowa initially refused to pay tribute, until Ahmed Pasha el Menekli, governor of Sudan, cruelly stamped out resistance in 1844. He wantonly slaughtered and mutilated the tribesmen, practising swordsmanship by trying to cut captives in half in one blow. Despite ending Hadendowa resistance, we have only established permanent control of their lands by constructing new outposts in Tokar, Erkowit and Temerein. To the South, the Beni Amer, an unwieldy tribe sandwiched unhappily between the Hadendowa and the Abyssinians, have come to terms with us and begun paying tribute, seeing the enemy of their enemy as their friend. Thus, our line of control has been extended to the banks of the Baraka river.
The Subjugation of the Northern Beja

The last independent Beja clans remained in and around Salala, in the hilly region of the Nubian Desert. Our army has tried multiple times to build forts in the area, but their resistance and the terrain have made these attempts fail. With them having been increasingly encroached on by our army and their sea access being lost to our control of the coast of the Red Sea, these clans have slowly started to pay tribute in a more consistent way, and have finally let our army build a post near Salala, finishing our conquest of the region.

Keren was originally a trading settlement on the Ethiopian frontier, laying on an arid highland plain between the Ansaba and Baraka rivers. The town owes its importance to its position on the trade route between Massawa and Sudan. Typically traded goods include cotton cloth from Sudan and ivory, skins, ostrich feathers and maize from Tigre. While forces have set out from the frontier along the Baraka River and looted Keren and its caravans in the past, our men have now finally permanently occupied it, securing the trade route and logistical connection from Massawa to Kassala for good.

Dallol is located in the Danakil Depression, an extremely hot, dry region rich in geothermal activity, possessing multiple volcanoes rich in sulfur. At 100m below sea level, the Awash River flows to multiple hypersaline lakes at the bottom of the depression. As these seasonally dry up, large deposits of salt are revealed. This salt has been mined for centuries and traded via caravans with the rest of Ethiopia, bringing large tax revenues to those controlling the trade. With our position on the Eritrean coast well established and Dallol under the control of weak, disorganized Afar clans, the valuable salt deposits are ours for the taking. Thus, an expedition has set out from our holdings and taken possession of Dallol.
The Conquest of the Eastern Desert

The Eastern Desert is the part of the Sahara desert located east of the Nile river, consisting of a mountain range which runs parallel to the coast, wide sedimentary plateaus extending from either side of the mountains and the Red Sea coast. While the region had been criss-crossed by trade routes during the Roman period, they fell into disuse and the port cities, including Berenice, became ruins. Between the 7th and 19th centuries, the Eastern Desert was virtually abandoned by all but the nomadic Beja. Now, with the construction of the Suez canal, trade has begun to slowly but surely pick up again, leading to the construction of outposts on the coast.

The coast of the Usambara is rich in trade and cotton, and is the source of the kingdom's richness. Some chiefs that rule to their name are Swahilis that are friendly to our state, and we have good relations with the Kingdom of Usambara, but we might want to get the region for ourselves.

The coast of the Usambara is rich in trade and cotton, and is the source of our kingdom's richness. Some chiefs that rule to our name there are Swahilis that are friendly to Oman, and they have asked Oman to liberate them. Oman has chosen to ask us first to cede it peacefully.

Paté has been in decadence for decades, and its navy and army can't control all of its territory efficiently. With the slave trade reviving and the European colonial powers encroaching in our coasts, we have no choice but to act and centralize our holdings in Zanzibar. Paté, though, is known for its mercenary armies, and its army still has some kind of funding. We could get a treaty ceding only half of their domains to us, in exchange of protection.

The Bond of 1844 is a pact brought forth by the British government in the Gold Coast, specified relationships between the British and the Fante chiefs. The bond would bring us under British protection to Ashanti raids, and bring peace to the region.

The Fante Confederacy, a state located in the Gold Coast, only survives thanks to our military support. To increase $COUNTRY_ADJ$ influence in the confederacy, our local administration in the city of Cape Coast has made a proposal to the Fante: We would grant them full protection against the Ashanti Empire in return for significant economic concessions.

With our expansion to the south, we started encroaching into Abysinnian territory, and skirmishes started appearing all over the line of contact. Ahmad Kashif wanted to make a punitive expedition against the Abyssinians. With a few troops he went forward and destroyed two villages, being met with resistance but taking a number of captives, among whom was a priest. Kenfu, in secrecy, raised an army to take revenge. With corruption rampant in our rear, incorrect intel arrived to Kashif, who thought that Kenfu's force was small. Khurshid Pasha sent 600 men, amounting to 1500 men counting the local forces. As Ahmad crossed over into Abyssinian territory, Kenfu advanced with an army of 20,000 men, who surrounded Ahmad's force and began attacking from all sides. We've got heavy losses, and we've stopped all encroachments, but we have occupied Gallabat thanks to the chaos of the battle, setting a new border with Gonder.

With Egypt's expansion to the south, they started encroaching into Abysinnian territory, and skirmishes started appearing all over the line of contact. Ahmad Kashif, an Egyptian official, wanted to lead a punitive expedition against the Abyssinians. With a few troops he went forward and destroyed two villages, being met with resistance but taking a number of captives, among whom was a priest. Gonder ruler Kenfu, in secrecy, raised an army to take revenge. With corruption rampant in their rear, incorrect intel arrived to Kashif, who thought that Kenfu's force was small, less than 3,000 men. Khurshid Pasha sent 600 men, amounting to 1500 men counting the local forces. As Ahmad crossed over into Abyssinian territory, Kenfu advanced with an army of 20,000 men, who surrounded Ahmad's force. They've got heavy losses and have stopped all encroachments, but have occupied Gallabat thanks to the chaos. Egypt has asked us for support against Gonder, as they want to continue.

With Egypt's expansion to the south, they started encroaching into our territory, and skirmishes started appearing all over the line of contact. Egyptian official Ahmad Kashif wanted to make a punitive expedition against us, and with a few troops he went forward and destroyed two villages, being met with resistance but taking a number of captives, among whom was a priest. Kenfu, in secrecy, raised an army to take revenge. With corruption rampant in the Egyptian rear, incorrect intel arrived to Kashif, who thought that Kenfu's force was small. Khurshid Pasha sent 600 men, amounting to 1500 men counting the local forces. As Ahmad crossed over into our territory, Kenfu advanced with an army of 20,000 men, who surrounded Ahmad's force and began attacking from all sides. Egypt got heavy losses, and we've stopped all encroachments, but they have occupied Gallabat meanwhile chaos was occurring due to the battle and demarcated a new border with us unilaterally.

With Egypt's expansion to the south, they started encroaching into our territory, and skirmishes started appearing all over the line of contact. Egyptian official Ahmad Kashif wanted to make a punitive expedition against us, and with a few troops he went forward and destroyed two villages, being met with resistance but taking a number of captives, among whom was a priest. Kenfu, in secrecy, raised an army to take revenge. With corruption rampant in the Egyptian rear, incorrect intel arrived to Kashif, who thought that Kenfu's force was small. Khurshid Pasha sent 600 men, amounting to 1500 men counting the local forces. As Ahmad crossed over into our territory, Kenfu advanced with an army of 20,000 men, who surrounded Ahmad's force and began attacking from all sides. Egypt got heavy losses, and we've stopped all encroachments, but they have occupied Gallabat. They may continue the encroachment, and we must prepare.

The Laikipia peoples live to our north, and are in an inevitable conflict with our kingdom. The Kwavi live in lands that once were part of our kingdom, and occupy them illegaly. We must take their territory and bring them where they belong.

'They decided to attack and completely overwhelm the Maasai... With this in view, they went down the Rift Valley, and as they feared being raided by the Maasai whilst they were away, they brought the whole of their stock, women, children and belongings, with them. When the Maasai heard that they were coming, they combined and came forth to meet them. They met the Laikipia north of Nakuru and after a desperate encounter, the Kwavi were gradually pushed backwards in a westerly direction. Not knowing the land, they were unaware that the crater of Menengai, whose wall drops sheer of the plain, was behind them. When near the brink, the Maasai army redoubled the attack, and the Kwavi turned suddenly to fly, and fled over the brink of the crater, those who were not killed by the enemy being precipitated to the bottom.' \nWith our conquest of the Kwavi, the majority of their people have perished in fierce battles. The destruction the war brought to the region would be remembered as the Second Mutai, meaning disaster.

The coast of the Geledi and Hiraabi has been ruled for centuries by Swahili and Mashriqi people, which act almost independently, some of them even having pacts with us for trade or protection. We should capitalize on these weaknesses and claim the Somali Coast!

After diplomats from both sides made pacts of friendship and trade, the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ decided to cede us Amanzimtoti. The reason is not certain, but the visible instability of the region and the seeching of protection from the European powers could be reasons that had an impact on the decision.

The Hlubi are in a state of chaos. Their inhabitants are under constant threats of massacre by its neighbors, and another scenario like the Mfecane would bring chaos to our region and strenghten the Xhosa, where the Mfecane brought immigration which was used for slavery and strenghtening its army. Should we let them move to Shayilanga where they could be a powerful ally?

Hlubi is in a state of chaos. Our inhabitants are under constant threats of massacre by our neighbors, and another scenario like the Mfecane would bring chaos to our region and strenghten Xhosa, where the Mfecane brought immigration which was used for slavery and strenghtening its army, which doesn't benefit Mpondo. We hope the Mpondo let us move to Matatiele where we could be a powerful ally...

Griqua is in a state of chaos. With precious goods being discovered on their land and the British encroaching into their borders with reasons to fire--greed, they have asked us to settle in Kokstad, where they could survive.

With precious goods being found in Kimberley, a large number of Boer diggers settled on the diamond fields near the junction of the Vaal and Orange rivers. The land where they settled was claimed both by the Griqua, where they frequently herded, and the Orange Boers. Some months ago, Transvaal President Marthinus Wessel Pretorius declared the diamond fields as Boer property and established a temporary government over the diamond fields. The administration of this body was not satisfactory to the Boers, the diggers, the Griqua or the indigenous Tswana. Tension rapidly grew between these parties until Stafford Parker, a former British sailor, organised a faction of the diggers to drive all of the Transvaal officials out of the area. At the settlement of Klipdrift, Stafford Parker declared the independent Klipdrift Republic, who began collecting taxes for the British Empire and asked us to impose our authority. Today, a Committee has been formed which has granted us Kimberley.

Some decades ago, our kingdom encompassed all land between the Venda and the Vaal river, and our people were free and prosperous. The Mfecane though made it collapse, and our people had to leave to the mountains to reorganize to conserve sovereignty, With the outsiders having been expulsed from Mosega, we can now claim what our people deserve!

Our people had lived for centuries in Delagoa Bay, and we were forced to the mountains because of the Mfecane, a period of war in Southern Africa which can be situated between 1810 and 1830. Now that we are powerful enough to hold our territory from invasions, we can return to our homeland!
Our kingdom has for centuries been a great state and the powerhouse of the region. Thanks to new weapons coming from Europe, we can now expand in all directions to form the Kaabu Empire.
Our people can't be limited by the Batè! A local named Samori Turé is building an army to bring greatness to the Mandinka peoples and we should join him!

Centuries ago, our people were united under a single banner, the flag of the Jolof Empire. The Jolof Empire fell under internal pressure, and the only kingdom left was the Kingdom of Wolof. With all of the parts of the Empire under our hand, we can now claim its title!
After the fall of Timbuktu, our kingdom became too weak to hold the title of Empire. With our territories regained, we can now become the Bambara Empire again!
With all territories inhabited by Senufos under our banner, we can form the Senufo Empire!
The Akan peoples have been separeted for centuries, and the Ashanti have been keeping it that way with the Fante-Ashanti wars. With our people reunited though, we can now form the Akan Empire.
We have lived in our current territory for centuries, but our peoples have never united. If we unite the lands of the Umbundu, we can finally bring the Umbundu under our flag!
The Luba-Lunda Empire system is obsolete! We should claim all neighboring lands and put an end to this worthless peace. Long live the Lunda Empire!

Mirambo is a Nyamwezi king, ruling over lands bordering Tambora, a vassal state of ours. His territorial claims, though, extend further than our territory, and he has a large army under his fist. If we let Mirambo rule our kingdom, we will be able to rule over the whole of the Tabora plateau!
Claim the Legacy of the Chwezi Empire

The Chwezi Empire was a mythical empire in the oral traditions of our people and existed before the balkanisation of the kingdoms of the Great Lakes. Now that we have subdued all of the other rulers we can claim their legacy!

With our deliverance from the Ottoman yoke, a critical moment lies before us concerning the presence of Turks within our nation. As our relations with the Ottoman Empire plummet, tensions rose in Belgrade, where the Ottoman garrison of the Belgrade fortress, one of few remaining vestiges of Turkish control, fired into the city, killing 50 in response to a riot against their presence in the city. This gives us justification to finally rid ourselves of the remaining Turks living in our country and expel them from our lands. They may have done nothing wrong, but this is seen as a necessary step towards achieving full independence from the Ottoman oppressors.
Another step towards the total liberation of Serbia.

With the acquisition of parts of Southern Serbia and the conclusion of the last conflict our nation was embroiled in, a question has arisen concerning the Albanian population of the recently acquired territories. Many Albanians already fled when our troops arrived to besiege major cities like Niš, where the Albanian quarter was burned when the city surrendered. Mosques were destroyed in Vranje, Leskovac and Prokuplje. In the hilly villages, whilst some fled, leaving behind their livestock and property, many local Albanians defended their villages and resisted our advances. Others abandoned their villages and headed to the mountains where they began employing guerrilla tactics against our army, though they were eventually driven out. We have decided to remove the potential fifth column in our newly conquered lands, expelling all remaining Albanians from it.

The remarkable tale of Thomas Stevens, the intrepid cyclist who embarked on a daring journey around the world, has captivated the imagination of the public. As news of his extraordinary feat reaches our nation, we are faced with a decision that could shape our approach to transportation and exploration.

The daring voyage of Nellie Bly, the intrepid journalist who set out to circumnavigate the globe in a record-breaking seventy-two days, has captured the imagination of people around the world. As news of her extraordinary journey reaches our nation, the public is being confronted with a simple reality: women are no less capable of handling themselves in traditionally male professions than men. This may spell a reckoning for society's gender roles.
This is a remarkable journalistic feat.

On May 22nd, an extreme earthquake struck central Kansu, killing 40,912 people, hundreds of thousands of domestic animals, and destroying large swathes of the region. \n\nThe epicenter of the earthquake was near Gulang, an agricultural town by the Northern Silk Road, though the earthquake was felt as far as 700km away. In Gulang, almost the only thing left standing was a 20m long section of the city walls and some decorated archways.

On June 29th, a violent earthquake struck southern California, causing 13 deaths and 8,000,000 dollars in damages. \n\nThe earthquake occurred at 6:44 AM, with the epicenter being located at the coastal city of Santa Barbara. Though much of Santa Barbara was destroyed, further disaster was prevented by the heroic actions of three citizens, who shut off the town gas and electricity, preventing a catastrophic fire.
The loss is large, but we shall rebuild.

On June 27th, a violent earthquake struck south-eastern Montana, causing 2 injuries and 150,000 dollars in damages. \n\nThe earthquake occurred at 5:21 PM, with the epicenter being located in the Clarkston Valley, near the small mining town of Townsend. 3 hours after the main-shock, a strong after-shock was recorded that also caused damage.

On May 31st, an extreme earthquake struck East Pashtunistan, causing between 30,000 to 60,000 deaths. \n\nThe epicenter of the earthquake was near Quetta, a major city high in the Baluchistani mountains. Much of the city was destroyed, with the infrastructure almost entirely in ruins. Tens of thousands were trapped under rubble, and countless corpses were found lying in the hot sun. All villages between Quetta and Kalat were destroyed.
We must prepare aid for the survivors.

Starting October 18th, a series of severe earthquake struck south-western Montana, causing 4 deaths and 3,000,000 dollars in damages. They began on the 18th at 10:48 PM,  with the epicenter being located near Helena, Montana's capital city. \n\nThe earthquakes displaced some 400 people. Most found space with friends or family outside of the damaged area by the end of the week. Many others lived in tents around the town for the next few weeks, either due to damaged property or for fear of aftershocks.

Potash, or fertilizer potassium, has recently been discovered in southern Alsace while searching for coal deposits. \n\nPotash is primarily used in the production of fertilizer, though it can also be used in the bleaching of textiles, the creation of glass, ceramics, and soap.
The Kokand are severely weakened by internal civil wars and careless spending, with their army not having a chance against ours. We must use this opportunity to start our great empire once again!

The Bukhara, as menacing as they are, have launched a war against us to take Khojent and weaken our state irreparably. Their Emir, Nasrullah Khan, has ordered the execution of Ali-Khan and Nodira of Kokand, and march their troops onto our lands, crossing the mountain chains. At the same time, the Kyrgyz, which we finally finished conquering in 1830, have now revolted against our rule.
