Ormon Khan has been declareed the Khan of a new Kyrgyz Khanate, and have started destroying our forts in Naryn and Bishkek. The Kurtka Fortress is the most important one, now being in siege. We hope for the best, but our future as a regional power is dwindling.

With the fall of the Middle Jüz, the remaining parts of the Kazakh Khanate, the Senior Jüz fell into decadence and wars with the Kyrgyz of the South, weakening further and becoming a great target for expansion. With this opportunity, we must prepare for a quick war to end the sovereignty of the Kazakh Jüzes once and for all, and while we're at it, we could get some Kyrgyz land.

On August 21st, an extreme earthquake struck the coast of South Carolina, causing 60 deaths and up to 6,000,000 dollars in damages. \n\nThe initial shock in Charleston lasted 45 seconds and was extremely destructive, leaving nearly all of the city with either interior damage or broken windows. The first aftershock followed minutes later, and had the city rumbling once again. In the next day, at least seven different aftershocks were felt in Charleston and its surrounding areas. The damage stretched out in a radius of a hundred miles. The quake was felt in cities as far as Boston and Chicago.
Let us pray that it does not happen again.
Liptako Has Used the Decision 'Launch a Jihad on Dendi'.
Claim the Throne of the Massina

The Massina and us had the same objective: unite the region under a same banner, one that had Islam in its center and one that would launch jihad at any pagan country that would be in its path. With our occupation of Massina being finished, we can now claim the Massina Throne on the basis of ideals. We have to bring Allah's name to every corner of the continent, and being separated isn't the way we should go.

The Yaka people have been under other states for far too long. Our people have been slaves, we have been borderly, we haven't been important to the great Empires of the region, just a rock to push around. Of course, we will not this continue. With our territories in the West being regained, we finally have the power to be the Empire over the others, a great Yaka Empire. We might, though, see that southwards expansion is what we truly need.

The outsiders, coming from the distant land of Europe and their allies, are getting closer and closer to our lands. The states that divide our people, not the Susu or the Bambara, but the Mande people as a whole, must be united under a single flag to keep off the Europeans and unite in our power. The Mande people must be united, and this will be the first step!
The Lunda people and their neighbors have been disunited for far too long! Our region should be united so we can resist the recent arrival of the Europeans.

Our country is the greatest that it has ever been, but its goal has still not been finalized: uniting the Bemba under a single flag. With the Kazembe out of the picture, now we can start waging war to unite the Bemba, from the Zambezi to the upper coast of the Tanganyika.

The Mfecane brought too much destruction to our region, with a lot of the population migrating to distant lands and losing contact to their mainland, and this one becoming empty of settlements or great kingdoms as it was before, and other countries taking their place but not being able to use the land for farming and falling weak on the steps on the Europeans. We must unite the region in the face of unity, to end this age of darkness.

Our once great empire had been brought into decadence by Portuguese and Omani incursions into our land and commerce empire. With the Omanis displaced from our rightful lands, we can now safely say the Kilwa Empire has returned!

The Egyptians have had a presence in our country for more than 10 years, it being more accentuated in Ha'il, to the Egyptians we owe our presence there not being enough  to centralize the region. With the Egyptian troops weak and trapped in Yemen and the Ottoman Empire in disarray, we should try stopping to pay tribute to the Egyptians and free ourselves.

The Nejd today have refused to continue the payment of vassalage, as they deem that we are weak enough for them to defend against any punitive expedition from Cairo. We should prove them wrong and continue our dominance over the Arabian Peninsula!

The Nejd have capitulated and returned to their state of vassaldom, paying their tribute to our great state. Our domains in the Arabian peninsula are again stable and should never fall again. With this in mind, we could try centralizing the states in the region under our rule, but that could be seen as an act of aggression from the Ottomans.

The Egyptians have finally left our lands for Cairo, and we are free from vassalage. With our newfound freedom, we could annex our neighboring states, but that could be seen as an act of aggression from the Ottomans.

For now decades, we have had influence and owned parts of the region to our west, the biggest city there being al-Mirfa, which ruler is our ally and has asked us for annexation more than once. In 1835, a section of the Bani Yas that had committed piracy against the British, trying to escape the consequences of their acts, had seceded from our state and settled in Odeid, near the Qatari border. With the news arriving to the British embassy, the local rulers of southern Qatar were prohibited from supplying the pirates, and set fire to some of the pirates' boats. After receiving approval from the British some days ago, we sent troops to occupy the region and sack their settlement, centralizing the region under our rule.

The Imam of Oman has gained influence of power over the last years, having fought a war against the Nejd and gaining positive relations with Abu Dhabi. He has made a campaign to gain followers and allies to centralize Oman under his rule, but they aren't powerful enough to beat us. With troops amounting just outside the city of Dhank, a bloody battle is on the horizon. Should we escalate further and unite Oman and Muscat or back down?

Tarfaya is a coastal city in the coast of the Tekna, south of Morocco, through which caravans go in the route from Timbuktu to Fez. Building a fort in the city could help us trade with the commercial caravans and Mohamed Bairouk.

Today, the British North West Africa Company occupied and took over Tarfaya as part of the Scramble for Africa, and turned it into an exchange center of trade in order to trade with Mohamed Bairouk and commercial caravans coming from Timbuktu and destined to Wadi Noun. We should intervene to keep our control over the caravan routes in the Western Sahara.

Key: BATTLETARFAYA:Today, local troops commanded by Moulay Abd al-Aziz have occupied Port Victoria and returned it to their domains, forcing all of our subjects our of the region.

English: Our country has been in a state of constant conquest since its inception, and now only has one route of expansion: to the West. The Mende, owners of the Western Grain Coast for centuries, now look weak in front of us. We shall claim their coast for Liberia to trull own all of the Grain Coast!

The Liberians have been in a constant state of conquest for now decades, and now eye for our coast. Now that they, a westerner-funded state, formally claim part of our land, we shall decide what to do in front of this act of aggression.

Our border in the East of Sierra Leone isn't demarcated, and the Liberian and our claims overlap over a series of river vallies in the frontier of the Grain Coast. With new stage in African colonialism, we could try to occupy part of these Liberian-claimed lands on the pretext of the borders that have been settled for the region, or draw our own line.

The British have started formally claiming part of our coast in the West, including Sahn, the frontier of the Grain Coast. We did take this land in an unequal treaty, but this doesn't mean the territory isn't rightfully ours, and less British. They, though, have to be taken seriously.

The British have started formally claiming part of our coast in the West, including Sahn, the frontier of the Grain Coast, and Kailahun, a city on the bank of the Makona River. We did take this land in a series of unequal treaties, but this doesn't mean the territory isn't rightfully ours, and less British. They, though, have to be taken seriously.

The British have started formally claiming part of our coast in the West, including Sahn, the frontier of the Grain Coast, and Kailahun, a city on the bank of the Makona River. They, though, also claim Cape Mount, one of our core territories, which is clearly an overextention of the border. We did take this land in a series of unequal treaties, but this doesn't mean the territory isn't rightfully ours, and less British. They, though, have to be taken seriously.
The Liberians have accepted our demands in the East of Sierra Leone, and our border has been settled.
The Liberians have rejected our demands in the East of Sierra Leone, insulting them for being an 'overextention' and not serious. We shall show them what's serious.
The British have refused to escalate our conflict on the border of Sierra Leone, and now we can keep our territories intact.

A dispute over Bolama has turned into an all-out crisis in the last days, with British and Portuguese ships facing each other without firing on the Bolama Coast. In 1792, a group of officers of the Royal Navy led an attempt to resettle Black former slaves from the Americas on the island of Bolama off the coast of Portuguese Guinea. Most of the settlers died and the survivors abandoned the colony in November 1793 and made their way to Settler Town in what later became Sierra Leone. In 1830 we started officially claiming the island, and a dispute developed. In the last years though, the British have had increasingly more influence on the island, and have claimed to have annexed the island. What should we do to end this crisis?
Bolama has been disputed for more than 40 years now, and an arbitration by Ulysses Grant has settled the crisis. The islands will now be ours.

A dispute over Bolama has turned into an all-out crisis in the last days, with British and Portuguese ships facing each other without firing on the Bolama coast. In 1792, a group of officers of the Royal Navy led an attempt to resettle Black former slaves from the Americas on the island of Bolama off the coast of Portuguese Guinea. Most of the settlers died and the survivors abandoned the colony in November 1793 and made their way to Settler Town in what later became Sierra Leone. We use this statement to claim the islands near Bolama, where recently a crisis has developed. The Portuguese had asked Ulysses Grant to arbitrate the dispute, and they have awarded them to Portugal.
In a strange set of events, Ulysses Grant has granted Bolama to the British.
With our great victory against the Moroccans, we can now recreate the great Kingdom of Sous!

With our efforts to centralize our state being heard all around Morocco, multiple tribes are gaining discontent on the Makhzen and refuse to cooperate. Some days ago, the Zemmour and other tribes in the vicinities of Miknas and Huribga got to arms and started an all-out revolt against Fez. Their demands, create an independent state in the South of Morocco.

With our efforts to centralize our state being heard all around Morocco, multiple tribes are gaining discontent on the Makhzen and refuse to cooperate. Some days ago, the Za'ir and other tribes in the historical region of Sous got to arms and started an all-out revolt against Fez. Their demands, create an independent state in the South of Morocco.

With our efforts to centralize our state being heard all around Morocco, multiple tribes are gaining discontent on the Makhzen and refuse to cooperate. Some days ago, the Zemmour, Banu Mousa and other tribes in the vicinities of Miknas, ad-Dar al-Bayda and Huribga got to arms and started an all-out revolt against Fez. Their demands, create an independent state in the South of Morocco.

With our efforts to centralize our state being heard all around Morocco, multiple tribes are gaining discontent on the Makhzen and refuse to cooperate. Some days ago, the Zemmour and other tribes in the vicinities of Miknas and Huribga got to arms and started an all-out revolt against Fez. Their demands, create an independent state in the South of Morocco.

After our decision to enact laws that prohibit the usage of patois, or non-French languages in schools, usage of humiliation and corporal punishments have become prevalent against children by their teachers. Clogging has become standard practice in our schools, with offenders having to wear objects such as clogs around their necks. Another example of suppression is our administration's usage of "la Vergonha" or "the shame" in order to alienate Occitan speakers from their own language, by painting it as a corrupted form of French, used by the ignorant and uneducated lower classes. In order to replace the languages of our minority groups with French, our prefects and sub-prefects have been instructed to focus on the annihilation of non-French languages. Although these practices have begun to show results, one cannot deny the inhumane nature of our new schooling systems, and it brings shame to the French system in its entirety. Still, there are many who support these practices, however, one cannot begin to wonder whether this will be seen as an act of unification- or a shameful system desperate to facilitate control over its subjects.

The Egba have been a thorn on our side for now more than a decade, and we have craved their west as much as Ijebu craves Badagry to be theirs. We must regain control over the rebellious provinces of the Egba and partition it under our and Ijebu's rule.

The Egba have been a thorn on our side for now more than a decade, and we have craved Badagry as much as Dahomey craves their west to be theirs. We must regain control over the rebellious provinces of the Egba and partition it under our and Dahomey's rule. This is the proposal that Dahomey has given us, and it might just be our last hope to do so before the British start meddling in our affairs.
The Dahomey and Ijebu have declared war on us to partition our state, and our army probably can't hold theirs for too long. Should we seech support from the British?

The Dahomey and Ijebu have declared war on the Egba to partition their state, and their army probably can't hold theirs for too long. As we have an informal alliance with them, should we help them survive?

The British are seeching to intervene in our war against Egba, and have issued the following ultimatum: \n\nOutlaw Slavery, stop all declarations of war against the Egba. If we don't comply, they will join the war and blockade out exports and imports by sea.
Our Ultimatum has succeeded, Dahomey outlawed slavery and our Yoruba ally is at peace.
After a lot of ultimatums by the British, the Dahomey have stopped all declarations of war. We are at peace!
The British have joined in the side of Egba, and Dahomey has had to agree to an ultimatum, ending our war.
Dahomey has refused to act upon our ultimatum, showing they think they are as powerful empire, spanning from sun to sun. We shall show the Dahomey who are they messing with.
The British have blockaded our ports, showing their naval strength. We might not be as powerful as we thought, and the British are on our coasts waiting for a final push.

Ghezo has died today by a shot on his back, coming from the other side of the square in which they were celebrating the Annual Costums. The assassin has been captured shortly after, and proclaimed allegiance to Abeokuta when asked about his motives. We can only know one thing: a sniper associated with the Egba has assassinated our great king, Ghezo I, and retaliation should be justified.

Our King, Kwaku Dua Panin, has suggested to us that we suggest the following pact to the Netherlands so we gain access to western guns: provide Ashanti recruits, a thousand of whom would join the Dutch East Indies Army within a year in exchange for guns. The soldiers would come from Ho, from our local Ewe regiment. With the prospect of army growth, we hope the Netherlands will provide us with what we need.

The King of Ashanti, Kwaku Dua Panin, in our visit to Sekondi has suggested us the following exchange: provide Ashanti recruits, a thousand of whom would join the Dutch East Indies Army within a year in exchange for guns. Shall we accept?

§RGain 3 infamy§! The countries to our North have repeatedly raided bordertowns for decades, and claim we are a rebellious province of theirs. With the latest raid, we have the casus belli needed to finally bring them down under our rule.

Now that our country has been centralized, we can now officially lay claim to our borderlads, which have been controlled by us sporadically over the last centuries but lost to greater states which now are under us. Long live Kaffa!
Create an Empire with Rabih az-Zubayr

Rabih az-Zubayr is a warlord from Khartoum which has been raiding our borderlands for now quite some time. Our border forces are barely holding them off, but letting Rabih inside our state to pact an union would stop such attacks and unite both armies into one. \n\n§RWarning: You have to merge the brigades that are generated by this decision§W
With Kanem, Bornu and Baguirmi weakening due to the encroachment of the European powers, we can now take them for ourselves.

Our Confederation is in disarray. 20 years ago, we had to leave our capital in Mankhamba due to internal disputes for the throne of the Maravi and the Chewa, and the city and its surroundings have fallen into disuse, with nomadic tribes taking over the region. Now, with the Ngoni taking over our Chewa neighbor in Mkamanga (which once was ours), they have now started raiding our borderlands, and even taken over part of our land and Mankhamba, which we also claim as ours. We have entered into a war we cannot win. Long live the Maravi Confederation!

With the Nguni raids into Maravi proving successful, it gives an opportunity to rise: the slave trade. If we expand our borders towards the coast and the lands of the Maravi, we will be able to rise as the greatest power in the region. Long live the Yao!

The Maravi operated a decentralised political system. With time, the system isolated and weakened the Kalonga, who often had no dependable relations locally. Sometime during the eighteenth century, perhaps due to the growing influence of the Banda clan, the requirement that Undi nominate Kalonga’s successors was no longer enforced which meant that counsellors of the Banda clan at Mankhamba assumed that responsibility. On the surface, it seemed sensible to appoint successors locally. After all, that was how they did it before Undi and Nyangu left. However, times had changed, and this time it did not work smoothly. Its decline there would not have meant much had Mankhamba not been the capital of the Maravi. In this case it did, because it shows that the pottery went into disuse at the site soon after its introduction, an indication that Kalonga and his people abandoned Mankhamba at about that time. Archaeological evidence shows that the site has remained unoccupied ever since.

Throughout the eighteenth century, a growing state of instability characterised the political situation in the Maravi empire. As territorial chiefs became increasingly independent, Kalonga’s grip on power and trade became weak. Other ethnic groups were quick to notice that weakness and they took advantage of it. The best known of those ethnic groups were the Yao in northern Mozambique who developed their own trade routes in the region. They became so successful that, by the 1740s, Portuguese merchants along the Indian Ocean coast recognised them as major traders and some foreign merchants encouraged them to trade in slaves as well. With the decadence of the Maravi, they themselves became the slaves that started to be traded by the Yao int he slave markets of Kilwa and Zanzibar, and with the Portuguese until 1833. We should recover the control over the trades that are conducted throughout the region and reform the Maravi to its greatness.
An outbreak of rinderpest has broken out in this province, and threatens to spread.
An epizootic of rinderpest has started in this province, and threatens to spread.
An epizootic of the rinderpest virus is striking Africa, killing the majority of our cattle in $PROVINCE$ and starting famines, which are wiping out sizable amounts of the local population.

In 1830, we were forced to pass a Hatt-i-Sharif, i.e. an imperial edict that granted Serbia far-reaching autonomy, sold all Turkish-held property therein and recognized Prince Miloš Obrenovic's right to form a dynasty. These humiliating demands were all part of the Treaty of Adrianople, signed after losing the Russo-Turkish War of 1828-29. We have, however, by stalling negotiations, avoided the treaty's worst part: Ceding 6 nahiyas on the Principality of Serbia's southern border to the Serbs. Now, Russia has put its foot down and threatened war if we continue to delay. Sadly, with our empire in the state that it is, we have little choice in the matter.

The Ottomans have ceded us 6 nahiyas on our southern border, fulfilling their final obligations as per the 1829 Treaty of Adrianople, which followed the Russo-Turkish War that had begun a year prior. These areas were controlled by noble Serbian freedom fighters during the war of independence but were retaken by the Turks shortly after. Now, thanks to the efforts of our Russian compatriots, our rightful territories have finally been returned.

France has declared war on us to annex Algiers, our capital, and in the meantime our vassals have freed themselves. We must put our kingdom together before we fall into chaos, or before France encroaches into us.
With wars all around us finally lowering in intensity, we can now settle in a new capital in Jimeta.

After regaining Fernando Pó from the British, generals like Juan Lerena y Barry have disembarked in the coast of the Gulf of Guinea, where Baltasar Simó and Francesc Vicent, Catalans from the Spanish Balearic Islands, advisors to Bonkoro I, king of the Benga people, had told him stories of the great lands of Europe and Spain, and of its great riches. Bonkoro decided to sign treaties with Juan Lerena y Barry, putting their kingdom in a protectorate. Today an expedition has reached Equatorial Guinea, and effective control has been established.
With our newfound power, we can reach the other Fula jihad states of the West and force them to stop their murders and forced conversion of our fellow brothers in religion.
Unite with the Fula Jihadi states
Now that we border each other, we can form an union to create the biggest Western Fula Jihad state to date.
Bornu is too weak to keep us as a vassal, and our kingdom hsa its own sphere of influence and enough manpower to defend against Waddai. We shall revolt and regain what belongs to us.
We have been under Sokoto for too long, which has impaired our ability to lauch jihads under our own volition. We shall leave them and fight for our sovereignty and Islam!

This update has a new mechanic for Emirates under the Sokoto Caliphate, the Autonomous Emirate mechanic. Gwandu - when formed by Sokoto and given its autonomy -, Adamawa - if Sokoto gives it more autonomy later on - and Ilorin will be allied to Sokoto for as long as they exist, until they are annexed, or until they have -190 relations with Sokoto and leave their alliance. If you are an Autonomous Emirate, you can stop being so, getting an event if you drop relatios under -190 and you leave your alliance - you though have to be fast, in a month you are allied again, so make sure to make leaving the alliance the last thing you do or relations will bump back with the alliance is added back. Your modifier will dissapear when you do so -. The modifier they have when they are Autonomous Emirates lets them always declare for cores, and if Sokoto refuses to help in a war this won't remove the Emirate condition.

Today our great Lamido, Lauwal bin Adama has died of disease. This is leading us to a succession crisis, as the new Lamido could be 2 people as for the succession principles: Hamidu, a warlord from Gurin which has part of the economy under him and has clients in Yola, and Sanda, half-brother of Lauwal, with the majority of the malams of Yola and the House of Alkassum, house of Adama's son-in-law. Though, there is an issue which divides public opinion, the malams have advocated for an end to the jihad for now some years. With this mounting, both candidates have sent letters to Sokoto to be handed the flag and become the Lamido. The opinion of the Caliph might weaken our state irrevocably.

The Lamido of Adamawa, Lauwal bin Adama, has died today due to disease, and the Adamawan lamidos have not been able to find a sole successor, having two valid options. The Sandites want us to have further control over them but want an end to the Jihad, and the Hamidites want to keep their current position and continue with the Jihad. The solution, though, isn't that easy: Hamidu holds a lot of power and might revolt anytime.

Sokoto has decided to give the flag to Sanda bin Lamido, half-brother of Lauwal and the chosen successor by Adama. It might seem like a good decision, but the Hamidites have prepared a revolt and hold a lot of power, and with them basically holding Yola hostage, they have declared independence.

Sokoto has decided to give the flag to Hamidu, lamido of Gurin, for his work in the jihad. The army, though, is with Sanda and refuses Sokoto's decision. They are in Yola, keeping the capital under their control, and Hamidu's forces, which outnumber them in guns, have surrounded the city. Fearing a civil war has already started, Hamidu has sent messages to Yola to capitulate. He has given them 7 days.

The seven days have passed, and this morning Hamidu's forces have encountered Hamidu dead of unknown causes. They are putting down their arms and moving back to Hibango, near to Gurin. We shall send a letter to Sokoto so they can give the flag to his successor, Sanda bin Adama.

After we gave the flag to Hamidu, Sanda's forces kept the capital, Yola, and the Hamidites mounted a siege for 7 days, with an ultimatum that in the eight day they'd assault the city with superior numbers. In the seventh day, Hamidu was found dead in the outskirts of Yola, with no known causes. Some Hamidites say it might have been an assassination, but most of them have laid down their arms and declared Sanda bin Adama as their successor. Must we give the flag to him?

This update has a new mechanic for states under Kanem-Bornu, the Affiliated State mechanic. Mandara will be allied to Kanem-Bornu for as long as they exist, until they are annexed, or until they have -190 relations with Kanem-Bornu and leave their alliance. If you are an Affiliated State, you can stop being so, getting an event if you drop relatios under -190 and you leave your alliance - you though have to be fast, in a month you are allied again, so make sure to make leaving the alliance the last thing you do or relations will bump back with the alliance is added back. Your modifier will dissapear when you do so -. The modifier they have when they are Affiliated States slows down their war declarations, but does not negate it completely and can always declare for cores, and if Kanem-Bornu refuses to help in a war this won't remove the Affiliated State condition.
We have been under Kanem-Bornu for too long, which has impaired our ability to defend correctly against Adamawa, under our own volition. We shall leave them and fight for our sovereignty!

In the North we shall find more Hausa states and holdings of the Bornu Emirate, lands which have tried to resist the jihad since its start in 1808. We shall end their resistance and form Emirates in their place!
Fombina, meaning south, used to be owned by the Emirate of Adamawa, now in decadence after we took Yola. As we can consider ourselves to be the successors to their state, we shall claim what is ours.
Expand the Extent of Our Jihad

Our Jihad has been contained for some years now, as kingdoms fortify in their local mountains and mount revolts against our Lamidos. With our newfound power, we can now lay claim to them and make them Lamidos of our own.
Settle for the Arrival of the Mahdi

Usman emphasized to Adama the importance of anticipating the coming of the Mahdi. Usman believed that the Mahdi would emerge from the east and urged Adama to be vigilant for signs of his appearance. Usman had prophesied that the caliphate's reign would last only until the arrival of the Mahdi, within a span of a hundred years. Sultan Bello (second Sultan of Sokoto) further requested Adama to send spies to "south of Wadai and the south of Fur in the direction of the Nile River" so that the people of the caliphate, on the Mahdi's appearance, could "follow him and give him the oath of allegiance."

Since the start of the Fula Jihads, we had to limit our power to the shores of the Chad and the Mandara Mountains, and ally and subsequently fall into the sphere of influence of Kanem-Bornu. Now we should regain our lands to the South, as the jihad states weaken more and more by the day.
Baguirmi is a state to our East, which has never really been friendly to us. If we claim Baguirmi for ourselves, we might end such a danger from our future.
Our kingdom once owned lands to the West of where we're located, but the Fulani Jihads pushed us to the Chad where we are now. We shall return to the lands which were taken from us!
Loango owns part of a region which encompasses most of the modern-day population of the Tio people: Anziku. We should reclaim this territory to reunite our people.
After some bloody battles, we have pacified the Makhzen and instated our rule over Morocco.

The land of Mauritania has been under our influence for centuries, but we have never been able to control the lands directly due to its geography. Now that we control lands to both sides of Mauritania, we can effectively control the region.

Our lands have been occupied by numerous kingdoms, from Darfur to Baguirmi. If we have to become a force to be reckoned with, we have to liberate our neighbor's lands from their oppressors and settle in Wara to create a new empire.
After the defeat of the Diriyah, polities in our north formed confederations of their own, which we rule loosely. We should centralize Ha'il now that we can effectively rule our own territory.

Multiple commissions have tried to determine where our border in Trujillo should fall, but to no avail. With our newfound international support, we have asked a Bourbon king of Spain to arbitrate the issue. After some weeks of discussions, they have ruled in our favour. Viva $COUNTRY$!

We have disputed Trujillo with $FROMCOUNTRY$ for now decades, but we had never sought to formalize our border. In recent months politicians from both sides have asked a Bourbon king of Spain to arbitrate the issue. After some weeks of discussions, they have ruled in favour of $FROMCOUNTRY$. Should we accept this diplomatic loss?
$FROMCOUNTRY$ has refused to acknowledge their loss of Trujillo, and still lay claim to the region. Should we retaliate?

Multiple commissions have tried to determine where our border in Nicoya should fall, but to no avail. With our newfound international support, we have been able to form an arbitration committee with representation from Costa Rica and Nicaragua to arbitrate the issue. After some weeks of discussions, it have ruled in our favour. Viva $COUNTRY$!

We have disputed Nicoya with $FROMCOUNTRY$ for now decades, but we had never sought to formalize our border. In recent months politicians from both sides have formed an arbitration committee with representation from Costa Rica and Nicaragua to arbitrate the issue to arbitrate the issue. After some weeks of discussions, they have ruled in favour of $FROMCOUNTRY$. Should we accept this diplomatic loss?
$FROMCOUNTRY$ has refused to acknowledge their loss of Nicoya, and still lay claim to the region. Should we retaliate?

Chief of Justice of the United States Charles Hughes has proposed to end the Guatemala-Honduras border dispute once and for all, with a commission from Chile, the United States and Costa Rica. If we accept, we might have a higher chance to get what's ours.

Chief of Justice of the United States Charles Hughes has proposed to $FROMCOUNTRY$ to end the Guatemala-Honduras border dispute once and for all, with a commission from Chile, the United States and Costa Rica. They have now asked us to approve the committee so they can proceed.

Chief of Justice of the United States Charles Hughes has proposed to $FROMCOUNTRY$ to end the Guatemala-Honduras border dispute once and for all, with a commission from Chile, the United States and Costa Rica. They have now asked us to arbitrate who is in the right in the dispute.

We were forced to relinquish our claims to Cauca, the southern regions of Colombia, in the early 1830s. The treaties though were forced upon us and we should not recognize them as legally binding, just justifications for our neighbours' conquests upon our territories.
With the Cauca under our control, we can now reclaim our borders from the times of Spanish colonization, which involves Acre, Cauca and parts of the Upper Amazon rainforest.
Muhammed Bello, our second Caliph since 1817, has had his health deteriorate in recent days, and has moved the capital of the Empire temporarily to Wurno, where he resides.

Muhammed Bello, our second Caliph since 1817, has died today at the age of 58, and quickly succeeded by his brother Abu Bakr Atiku. Some Emirs had tried to not let him reign as he is unpopular in the Eastlands of the Caliphate, notably Fombina. He has also banned dancing and music, and moved the capital back to Sakkwato.

Abu Bakr Atiku has decided today to declare Adamawa a Subordinate Autonomous Emirate, a condition similar to Ilorin's. This has pleased most of the Caliphate but angered Katsina and Gwandu, which remain as vassals.
Abu Bakr Atiku has decided today to declare Tibati an Emirate of the Sokoto Caliphate, and not one of Adamawa. This could cause Adamawa to revolt against us.

Abu Bakr Atiku, our third Caliph since 1837, has died today at the age of 60, and has been succeeded by Ali Babba bin Bello, who is known for its centralization policies as a local Emir of Gwandu. We hope he is able to quell the revolts that have recently started all over the Empire.
Revolts have started all over our Caliphate, from Kebbi to Namoda. We should be able to quell them, but not under Atiku.

Hadejia has revolted with the rest of Emirates to the Northeast of our Caliphate, and have joined the Bornu for protection. Should we go to war or try to pact to not create more instability in the region?
Hadejia has revolted against the Sokoto Caliphate and went to war against them, at the same time as claiming to be part of our state. Sokoto has subsequently attacked our army in our borderlands.

Hadejia has revolted against the Sokoto Caliphate and went to war against them, at the same time as claiming to be part of our state. Sokoto thankfully has decided to pact with us a treaty of friendship, so we do not have to go to war over a false claim.

The recent discovery of the Bessemer Process has made the metallurgy industry boom in recent months, with factories being built all over Asturias, the Basque Country and Alicante, and iron mines being opened all over the Southwest and Northwest of Spain.

The $COUNTRY$ Confederacy has survived the Fulani jihad thanks to its formidable army, and a lot of bordering territories were lost in the struggle for sovereignty. We must retake them and place our rule over them.
Having centralized our state on Manjacaze, we now can start raiding northly, to get to the Zambezi River and liberate our brothers in the region.

The Gambia colony, first established on James Island in 1815, has grown bit by bit through territorial acquisitions achieved by concluding treaties with the natives. The lower river is now almost entirely under our control and has seen significant economic development through the establishment of lucrative peanut plantations. Neighboring French Senegal has been expanding at a comparatively voracious pace, and our Gambian colonial officials have come to realize that little time remains to expand into upper Gambia before the French take it for themselves.

The Ngoni were expulsed from their lands some decades ago, and have been raiding the lands of the Limpopo River for the time being. Now, the Gaza and our state have been in rising tensions, and in some years a war will determine who will form a sole Nguni state in the region. If we lose, we may migrate to the lands of the Maravi, from where stories come of great agricultural regions and unsettled swathes of pasture.

The Ngoni were expulsed from their lands some decades ago, and have been raiding the lands of the Limpopo River for the time being, and after it were displaced to the Zambezi. Now, the Chidima and our state have been in rising tensions, and in some years a war will determine if will be able to form a Nguni state in the region. If they attack us, though, we might be forced to flee northwards.
The war has finally started, with soldiers from both sides preparing fortifications and ceremonies to declare each pretender the king of the Limpopo.

Manyika is a vassal of ours to the North of our state. It has served its purpose of being a buffer between the Portuguese Zambezi and our empire, but now we can proudly say we can face them without any need to have a buffer.
The Zarma from Dendi have been warriors for centuries, fighting off all foreign powers from their land. We should let some enter our country so they can help us defend ourselves.

King Monze has been gaining followers all over the region and is known as a Prophet of Rain. He is known to have been able to cause rain and cure sickness. We could turn our kingdom into a Theocracy of Rain, Mvwulabwami.
Our cattle have been going down in number due to local plagues, and our people have been massacred to the East. To be able to continue existing, we have to raid the baTawana.

Our raid against the baTawana has been successful, but we can no longer sustain our population. We need to settle somewhere else, somewhere where there's available farmland and the people there won't resist our rule enough to expulse us. We are lucky, the Lozi to our north are weak, and we could annex their farmland and claim their throne.
Grant Equal Rights to the Natives

The Kru, Susu and other people groups that are not Afro-Liberian are more than 90% of the population, but they are discriminated against by our administration. To become a functioning country, we have to grant them equal rights.

Located between the Syr Darya, the Amu Darya and the Aral Sea, The Kyzylkum Desert is the 15th largest desert in the world. The territory consists mainly of an extensive plain at an altitude up to 300 meters above sea level, with a number of depressions and highlands. Most of the area is covered with dunes. While the desert is economically and strategically nearly irrelevant, we have taken control of it to prevent it being used as a base for raiders and bandits.
The French have been oppressing our brothers for far too long. We should claim the region and restore the Occitan language and culture as one of prestige.

After the Fourth Anglo-Mysore War, the British East India Company assumed indirect control of the Kingdom of Mysore through a subsidiary alliance with the Wodeyar dynasty. Wasteful expenditure, ill-considered grants of land to undeserving courtiers and courtly intrigue between the royal family and its advisors have caused a decline in revenue, and our economy is in shambles, causing the administration to try to find new ways to collect taxes. Keladi, in the Northwest of Mysore, was annexed by us in wars against the Vijayanagara Empire some decades ago, and the local system of land revenue has been forced to drastically change from a highly popular system all around the region to one lending into corruption and contractors not abiding by their contracts. The local population has been gathering in mass meetings, called Kuttams, and have proclaimed a Kingdom of Nagar and started a guerrilla war against us.

The king's local administrators have been unable to quell the rebellion, and he has appointed Kishen Rao as the new administrator. Battles are raging throughout the North of our country, meanwhile the EIC has sent us an ultimatum threatening us with an overthrowal.

After the Fourth Anglo-Mysore War, the British East India Company assumed indirect control of the Kingdom of Mysore through a subsidiary alliance with the Wodeyar dynasty. Wasteful expenditure, ill-considered grants of land to undeserving courtiers and courtly intrigue between the royal family and its advisors have caused a decline in revenue, and their economy is in shambles, causing the administration to try to find new ways to collect taxes. Keladi, in the Northwest of Mysore, has been affected with concurrent and unpopular land reforms, making it fall from a highly popular tax collecting system all around the region to one lending into corruption and contractors not abiding by their contracts. The local population has been gathering in mass meetings, called Kuttams, and have proclaimed a Kingdom of Nagar and started a guerrilla war against Mysore. This has caused the king to abdicate, and the EIC has taken over the kingdom.

After the Fourth Anglo-Mysore War, the British East India Company assumed indirect control of the Kingdom of Mysore through a subsidiary alliance with the Wodeyar dynasty. Wasteful expenditure, ill-considered grants of land to undeserving courtiers and courtly intrigue between the royal family and its advisors have caused a decline in revenue, and their economy is in shambles, causing the administration to try to find new ways to collect taxes. Keladi, in the Northwest of Mysore, has been affected with concurrent and unpopular land reforms, making it fall from a highly popular tax collecting system all around the region to one lending into corruption and contractors not abiding by their contracts. The local population has been gathering in mass meetings, called Kuttams, and have proclaimed a Kingdom of Nagar and started a guerrilla war against Mysore. After the EIC threatened the kingdom with an intervention, they have unhonored our alliance and raided us.

Burgabo is controlled by different Somali tribes, from the Ogaden to the local Boqow. They are unorganized and they rule in a decentralized manner, not correctly controlling the region. With the European powers encroaching on the continent, Burgabo is an easy prey for us, but also the other colonial powers. We should occupy the city and its surroundings, as the holders of Mombasa and Muqdisho have claimed it since the 1820s and we already hold influence in the region.

The Tsonga people have never been united in a single state, but confederations of various sizes. With the Gaza occupying most of the Tsonga region, the Tsonga have started a new nationalistic movement to regain independence and form a new state. As part of the Tsonga people, we could use this opportunity to form an united Tsonga state.

The Kong Empire, named after its capital, also called Wattara Empire after its royal family, has a history that goes back more than 2 centuries. Our peak of power had its borders from the gates of Kumasi and Wadadugu to the approaches of the Niger River. We shall reconquer what's ours!

The Oasis of Buraimi and al-Ain have been under our influence for decades, and they have been taken over in recent years by the Omanis and Abu Dhabians. They constitute a core part of our kingdom and we shall claim them for ourselves!

§RGain 5 infamy§! Our Emir, Dost Mohammad Khan, aims to expand his influence in Bamiyan and Turkistan. He has proposed to send an American mercenary by the name of Josiah Harlan with an army to conquer the region. Josiah Harlan would ally with local forces and occupy the region, which could serve of great purpose to our kingdom. The region that would be conquered is, of course, Kunduz and its vassals, which have been in decline for now quite some time.
These are not the attacker's cores
These are not the attacker's cores

Abuja has been resisting attempts to peacefully annexing the local Igala kingdoms, vassals of their respective kingdoms, and Nupeland's borderlands are rebellious and raid our bordering emirates. Those lands clearly have to be brought to our jihad to secure our hold on Ilorin. §RDeclare war against Nupe if it exists§!
Zuru has been resisting attempts to peacefully annexing the local Borgawa kingdoms. Those lands clearly have to be brought to our jihad to secure our hold on Nupeland.

The Northern Bakongo have been oppressed for far too long! The Portuguese and Kongolese have a strong hold on the Southern Bakongo, and have been raiding us for centuries. We should expand southwards and end this menace!

An incident has occurred in Fashoda, Sudan, in which our expeditionary force led by Jean-Baptiste Marchand and its 130 soldiers, searching to occupy Sudan and claim control over a coast-to-coast colonial holding in Africa, has met in Fashoda another expeditionary army, first thought to be Dervish but later known to be British, led by Herbert Kitchener, which had just defeated the Mahdists in a battle near Khartoum, and was under constant guerrilla warfare attacks. Both forces in Fashoda have insisted on their right to control Fashoda but have agreed to wait for further instructions from their mainlands, jointly occupying the city. The British camp, though, distributed propaganda detailing how we aren't able to help Fashoda. Any battle produced there would clearly be suicidal, but ceding to the British would be a national humiliation.

An incident has occurred in Fashoda, Sudan, in which our expeditionary force led by Herbert Kitchener and its 1500 soldiers, searching to occupy Sudan and claim control over a coast-to-coast colonial holding in Africa, has met in Fashoda another expeditionary army, first thought to be Dervish but later known to be French, led by Jean-Baptiste Marchand and its 130 soldiers, which had just defeated the Mahdists in a battle near Waw, and was under constant guerrilla warfare attacks. Both forces in Fashoda have insisted on their right to control Fashoda but have agreed to wait for further instructions from their mainlands, jointly occupying the city. The French, upon a possible war between France and the British Empire, has ceded Fashoda to us and relinquished all claims to Sudan.

An incident has occurred in Fashoda, Sudan, in which our expeditionary force led by Herbert Kitchener and its 1500 soldiers, searching to occupy Sudan and claim control over a coast-to-coast colonial holding in Africa, has met in Fashoda another expeditionary army, first thought to be Dervish but later known to be French, led by Jean-Baptiste Marchand and its 130 soldiers, which had just defeated the Mahdists in a battle near Waw, and was under constant guerrilla warfare attacks. Both forces in Fashoda have insisted on their right to control Fashoda but have agreed to wait for further instructions from their mainlands, jointly occupying the city. The French, upon a possible war between France and the British Empire, have ignored the danger and occupied Fashoda and the rest of Southern Sudan. Should we consider this an act of war?

We had been part of the Kilwa Empire, and our lands became very wealthy thanks to newfound trade routes from the interior of the continent, bringing ivory and slaves. Those days have been over for centuries, but we can still bring them back. With our military reformed and the Portuguese pulling back on their control over trade in the continent, we can now retake what's ours.

The rulers of Fezzan have been at war against our local rulers in Tarabulus ever since we reinstated our rule in the region and overthrew the Tripolitanian dynasties. They claim to have an embassy with France, and they get arms from an unknown trade network. All we know is that they are a thorn in our side, and they should be brought back to Ottoman direct rule.

Ghuma al-Mahmudi has kept his control over Qaryat ever since we took over the Tripolitanian region of Fezzan, mantaining control with a sort of guerrilla warfare that reminds of the Peninsular War. Our local army has struggled to mantaim control over the cities and oasis bordering his zone of control, but division in his ranks has made it easier to start regaining control. He was exiled in the 1840s after the defeat of his armies, but with British help he has been able to return to Djebel Gharbi and organized another resistance movement.
The Senusiyya have resisted fiercely our occupation of Libya, and now aim to expulse us from Tripolitania.

Muhammad ibn Ali as-Senussi was born in Algeria near Mostaganem and was named al-Senussi after a venerated Muslim teacher. He was a member of the Walad Sidi Abdalla tribe, and was a sharif. Al-Senussi was critical of the government of Muhammad Ali Pasha. He argued that learned Muslims should not blindly follow the four classical madhhabs (schools of law) but instead engage in ijtihad themselves. Senussi went to Mecca, where he joined Ahmad ibn Idris al-Fasi, the head of the Qadiriyya, a renowned religious fraternity. On the death of al-Fasi, Senussi became head of one of the two branches into which the Qadiriyya divided, and in 1835 he founded his first monastery or zawiya, at Abu Qubays near Mecca. After being forced to leave by the Wahhabis he has returned to Libya, where he has founded places of teaching, where he teaches his believes under a new religious fraternity, the Senussiya. They have grown in political power, and control swathes of desert in Cyrenaica.

Our ally with which we've fought a World War owns the region of Jubaland, rich in resources and originally partially annexed from our colony of Somalia. Our ally remains weak, and could lose the next World War, so we could make them cede Jubaland in exchange of remaining allied, as it seems like the alliance hasn't really benefited us yet.

Our ally with which we've fought a World War, $FROMCOUNTRY$, owns the region of Somaliland. We remain weak from the World War, and need them to remain allied to us. We could cede Jubaland to them or lose a strategically important alliance with one of the Great Powers.

Our ally with which we've fought a World War owns the region of Anai and Angram, originally partially annexed from our colony of Tripolitania and Fezzan. Our ally remains weak, and could lose the next World War, so we could make them cede Anai and Angram in exchange of remaining allied, as it seems like the alliance hasn't really benefited us yet.

Our ally with which we've fought a World War, $FROMCOUNTRY$, owns the region of Tripolitania and Fezzan. We remain weak from the World War, and need them to remain allied to us. We could cede Anai and Angram to them or lose a strategically important alliance with one of the Great Powers.
Our Kingdom has been under the influence of the Aro Confederacy for far too long. We must take the lands of those that have oppressed us and form our own Empire!

Our Confederacy has been weakened by its rivals for far too long. We should bring the lands that we have coveted for far too long under our control and finally reaching our goal of a state for all Ibos!

Our kingdom has been resisting raids by the Igbo and Yoruba for decades, but we once were an Empire spanning lands that are now controlled by our enemies. We should retake our lands and create a kingdom that will never fall!

The Dervish Movement is a Somali-led movement that aims for Somali independence from our rule and other countries' colonies. It also aims to remove the European influence from Somalia and restore the "Sufi system of governance with Sufi education as its foundation". They control the interior of the Ogaden, and are fierce fighters, though low in numbers. Should we attack and reclaim more of Somalia?

The European colonial powers have been launching expeditions into the interior of Africa for decades, and our own empire seems small compared to their colonial empires. Abyssinia, a state to our south, is considered internationally to be backwards and easily conquerable by a colonial power. We should have a try at it and expand our empire!

The European colonial powers have been launching expeditions into the interior of Africa for decades, and our own empire seems small compared to their colonial empires. A state to our north is considered internationally to be less backwards and not easily conquerable by a colonial power. We should have a try at it and expand our empire, teaching them who really is backwards!
The $COUNTRY_ADJ$ Expedition to the Eastern Horn

§RGain 5 infamy§! As we have started the expedition to Ethiopia, we have brought attention to Harar and Somaliland, which are unclaimed by the colonial powers. We could try to claim them for ourselves!

Kassa Hailu, also known as Tewodros, has been raging war in Begemder for years now, and the war has been brought to a final battle in Ayshal. He has been able to win the battle, and the majority of our kingdom lays under him.

With the capitulation of Madagascar, they have agreed to our annexation of Antsiranana and paid us about 10 million francs. It also included an 'Instructive Letter' which was to clarify the treaty, but it was never presented to the French Parliament when the treaty was ratified.

The Imerina have yet again refused to acknowledge our demands, now those being their protectorate status. Upon our declaration of war, rebellions have started all around the kingdom, so the invasion could as well be easier or more difficult than expected.

As part of the government's efforts to modernize Japan, mandatory military conscription for all male citizens was recently introduced, which has come to be known as a "blood tax" among the peasantry.  Incited by this unpopular policy, as well as anger at the emancipation of the Burakumin minority and the institution of mandatory public schooling, hundreds of thousands of peasant farmers and rural samurai have risen up in rebellion. The revolt has spread across ten prefectures, including Kyoto, Okayama, Fukui, Mie, Tottori, Hiroshima, Shimane, Kagawa, Ehime, and Kochi. Government offices, police stations, newly established public schools, and the homes of government officials and newly emancipated Burakumin are being looted and destroyed en masse by the angry rabble. They have armed themselves with bamboo spears, guns, and swords, easily overwhelming the outnumbered local police.
Become the Negus of Shewa, Ifat, the Oromo and the Gurage

In 1828, Sahle Selassie had proclaimed himself Negus of Shewa, Ifat, the Oromo and the Gurage, but revolts, disease and famines made him never use these claims. Within our current position, an expansion to the East, South and West can be achieved, bringing prosperity to our great state.

After the Russian Empire utterly defeated us in the Russo-Turkish War of 1828-29, they forced us to sign the Treaty of Adrianople. It includes several provisions concerning Serbia, including granting the Serbs freedom of movement throughout our empire, confirming their privileges within their principality, ceding 6 nahijas to it, selling all Turkish-owned property located in it to Serbs and allowing Prince Miloš Obrenovic to form a dynasty. Originally, the Russians demanded that we fulfill their demands a month after the treaty, but so far we have been able to successfully stall negotiations. Now, their patience has worn out: While we can delay the cession of territory to the Principality of Serbia for a few more years, if we do not grant Serbia autonomy and implement the other demands immediately, Russia may declare war. Though it would be madness after our previous defeat, some advisors are advocating for an attempt to reconquer Serbia, whatever the cost.

In 1829, Sultan Mahmud II signed the Treaty of Adrianople after being defeated in the Russo-Turkish War of 1828-29. Its provisions included granting us further autonomy and ceding us territory to our South. The dastardly Turks have, however, continually stalled for time and refused to submit to Russia's demands. Now, they have played their true hand: The Ottoman Empire has launched a surprise attack, renouncing the Treaty of Adrianople entirely and aiming to reconquer our principality. While Russian aid is surely on the way, we must brace ourselves for what will hopefully be our third and final war of independence.

In 1829, Sultan Mahmud II signed the Treaty of Adrianople after being defeated in the Russo-Turkish War of 1828-29. Our demands included increasing the autonomy of Serbia as well as ceding it more territory. Since the signing of the treaty, the Turks have dragged their feet and avoided fulfilling the treaty's obligations. Now, their secret motivation has been revealed: They were planning to invade the Principality of Serbia all along! If we do not intervene on Prince Miloš Obrenovic's side, this may spell the end for the Serbians and destroy our international reputation.

When our savior, Tsar Nicholas I of Russia resoundingly defeated the tyrant Sultan Mahmud II in the Russo-Turkish War of 1828-29, he forced the Turks to sign the Treaty of Adrianople. Its demands included giving our people freedom of movement throughout the Ottoman Empire, confirming our privileges, being ceded 6 nahijas to the South, forcing the Turks to sell all property in our principality to us and allowing Prince Miloš Obrenovic to form a dynasty. After the perfidious Ottomans delayed negotiations for months, Russia has finally put its foot down and forced them to accept all demands save for the border adjustments, which require further discussion. Though we are still nominally subservient to the Sultan, the Principality of Serbia is now functionally independent thanks to the efforts of our Russian benefactors.

The Mahdists control the port of Massawa, strategically important to the region, and their hold onto it is weakening day by day. The city has suffered battles in which the Mahdists have expulsed the Egyptian garrison, and major forts have been destroyed. We could use this situation to occupy Massawa and continue expanding our colony in Eritrea.

The port of Massawa is strategically important to the region of Eritrea to the west of our colony in Assab, and its owners are increasingly in a cycle of destruction, with their army being weak compared to our great armed forces. We could use this opportunity to lay claim to Massawa on the grounds of protecting our comercial interests in the region.

The port of Massawa is strategically important to the region of Eritrea to the west of our colony in Assab, and we consider it as part of Eritrea. The current occupiers of Massawa mantain their control over the region, but we must finally take it.

The Funj Sultanate, also called the Blue Sultanate, was ruled by the Nuba Funj people and represented the biggest power in the region before Egyptian encroachment. The Funj converted to Islam some centuries before it fell to Egypt, but nevertheless we can found a state in its place without their mistakes.

Our lands have long been controlled by the Pagans and the Sokoto Caliphate, which have oppressed our people. Now that we're an independent nation, we can use this opportunity to liberate our brothers and sisters and convert the Pagans to God's faith. In the name of the Jihad, long live Ilorin!
Claim the Throne of the Oyo

With most of the Yoruba being now under our control and them converting to Islam, we could claim the Oyo Empire's throne on the basis of the center of Yoruba power having moved to Ilorin. The Pagan Empire shall give way to ours!

§RGain 3 infamy§! The lands to the East of the Ethiopian highlands have long been under the control of Muslim rulers and under the influence of the Ottoman Empire and, more recently, Egypt. With our resurgence as a regional power, we must claim the region for ourselves.

Protests in Malta have sprung into outright rebellion after the defacing of the Maltese flag with a Union Jack flying above the A la Ville de Londres, after a couple of hours protestors then attacked an officers' club smashing windows and hurling insults at the officers inside after several hours more hours and even more clashes with both soldiers and their officers, shots were fired into a crowd at the Cassar Torreggiani house which resulted in 4 dead and over 50 injured.

With our conquest of the Kingdom of Dahomey having finished, the confederacies and city-states to the West and North of Dahomey are up for the taking. We must take it before the colonizers of Togo take it!

The Anlo, a subtribe of the Ewe, reside in southwestern Ghana. Since their arrival in the 18th century, they have fiercely maintained their independence and rejected any collection of duties or taxes. Now, an expedition into the lands of the Anlo has completely defeated their unorganized and technologically inferior warriors. The independence of the Anlo is effectively at an end, with a treaty of protection sealing their fate for good.

A descendant of the Fulani Denianke Dynasty, Maba was born in 1809 a member of the Bâ family of the region of Rip, also known as Badibou. His grandfather had immigrated from Futa Toro, and the family were all teachers of the Quran. Maba studied in Cayor and taught in Kingdom of Jolof, where he married a member of the royal family, then returned to Rip around 1850. The local ruler of Badibou (Rip) in the 1850s was Mansa Jeriba. He was a weak ruler, and his warriors would frequently raid marabout villages in the area. Maba was the court marabout, frequently making amulets and praying for the king, but also attempting to weaken him by magical means and stockpiling weaponry. When the local ruler launched a new campaign of raids and the Marabouts retaliated he tried to crush the resistance, but Maba and his students defeated him. This success attracted more supporters, and he has been able to gain control over Eastern Saloum.

A descendant of the Fulani Denianke Dynasty, Maba was born in 1809 a member of the Bâ family of the region of Rip, also known as Badibou. He has been able to gain control over Eastern Saloum and is the chief marabout of Saloum. Maba Diakhou Bâ has offered us asylum in his state and being able to lead an army in his ranks, in exchange of our conversion to Islam. It might not be the best deal, but it ensures our survival.

Some months ago, the French started a campaign of massacres and scorched-earthing in Kayor, which the Kayor are not prepared to win. We proposed to the King of Kayor, Lat Jor, a deal - we protect him from the French and give him an army to launch campaigns, and in exchange he becomes part of our army and converts to Islam. He and his army of 500 animists have joined our ranks, and our position strenghtens.
Convert the Lands West of the Senegal to Islam

The Kingdoms of Wolof, Saloum and Sine have sizable minorities and, in certain regions, politheist and/or animist majorities. These kingdoms accept these non-believers, and even lets them form part of their aristocracy. We must stop these infidels from governing in the lands of our neighbours, and convert them to the only, true religion - Islam.
Maba Diakhou Ba is starting jihads all around his state, converting all non-Muslims in his territory and raided lands. He has demanded that we convert to Islam, or we'll face consequences.

The Oromo people have inhabited the lands of Ethiopia since 400 years ago, and live all around the region, from the land of the Gumuz to Borana and Harar. With our empire growing, we can no longer be considered a Leqa, but an empire for all Oromo.

Gwiriko has started a revolt against our rule, as its Dyula population demands less discrimination and more control over the taxing of the region. The Bobo people aren't happy either, and have unified under the Gwiriko once more. We must quell this rebellion, or we will look weak to the rest of the minorities we now rule over.

The Borgu Confederacy and its people, the Bariba, have long been under the influence of Islamic scholars, and a minority of the Bariba population is Muslim. To protect our brothers and sisters and help the rest of the Bariba know the word of Allah, we need to make Sunni Islam the state religion of the Borgu Confederacy.

$FROMCOUNTRY$ has long been seeching that we convert to Islam, but it has long been unsuccessful. In another of their attempts, they have asked us to convert - but with their armies now to the other side of the Niger we might have to accept.

$FROMCOUNTRY$ has started a campaign to convert our people, the Bariba, to Islam. They have long been unsuccessful, but with their armies now to the other side of the Niger they have started claiming our territory as theirs, to protect the Muslims in our state and convert the rest.

The Sherbro people inhabit Sherbro Island and the coasts to its north. With our control and influence over the region expanding, numerous Sherbro chiefs have signed treaties with our authorities so we can establish a protectorate.

With our declaration of war to the Afar and the Emirate of Harar, our navy has moved to cripple their economies. The only ports that were free from our influence or control were Bulaxaar and Barbara, both under the control of the Isaaq. The Isaaq have a powerful army and an existent navy, but they knew they could not last long against our wrath, as they were facilitating trade for Harar. With our great navy having moved to blockade Bulaxaar and Barbara, and with the Isaaq seeing their defeat written on the wall, they have decided to salvage what they could - letting us occupy Bulaxaar and Barbara.

Last May, Richard Francis Burton, the most documented non-Muslim European to make the Hajj, supported by the Royal Geographical Society, travelled to Aden in preparation for his expedition to Somaliland. His first stop was at Zayla, where he met the local Egyptian ruler, Sharmakay bin Ali Salih. Disguised as an Arab merchant, he awaited word that the road to Harar was safe. In Sagharrah, in the path to Harar, he openly proclaimed to be an English officer. According to Burton, "A tradition exists that with the entrance of the first [white] Christian, Harar will fall." With Burton's entry, the "Guardian Spell" was broken. He was graciously met by the Harari Amir, officially a guest of the Amir but in reality his prisoner. He's already walking the path to the coast, in Berbera, where he wants to prepare to set out in search of the source of the Nile.

When Burton arrived to Berbera, Burton prepared to set out in search of the source of the Nile, accompanied by Lieutenant Speke, Lieutenant G. E. Herne and Lieutenant William Stroyan and a number of Africans employed as bearers and expedition guides. The schooner HCS Mahi delivered them to Berbera on 7 April. Yesterday, Burton's camp was encountered by three horsemen, one Mohammed of the ‘Isa Musa, and another Dublay of the Ayal Ahmed, the third unknown. Burton's camp had mistaken them for a foraging party and quickly discharged above the horsemen. Today, his party has been attacked by a group of Isaaqi warriors, numbering about 200. Stroyan has been killed, Speke has been wounded in 11 places before his scape and Burton has been impaled with a javelin, the point entering one cheek and exiting the other. He has escaped with the weapon still transfixing his head. Rumours have reached us that the Senussi Order might have a hand in this.

Richard Francis Burton, a British officer, has been for the past year in an expedition throughout Somaliland, from Zayla to Harar. Some days ago he arrived to Barbara, where he was preparing for an expedition to the African Great Lakes. Yesterday, Burton's camp was encountered by three horsemen of our royalty. Burton's camp had mistaken them for a foraging party and quickly discharged above them. Today, his party has been attacked by a group of our warriors, numbering about 200. Burton has been impaled with a javelin, the point entering one cheek and exiting the other. He has escaped with the weapon still transfixing his head. This has lead to a diplomatic crisis with the British, whom have implemented a blockade on our ports, crippling our economy. They ask for the surrendering of the three horseman who, in their perspective, were "spying" on them.

The British Empire has won once again. The Habr Awal of Berbera, at first deemed it ironic. Due to the Habr Awal believing the blockade would not only suffer the trade in Berbera, but also in Aden. However they were mistaken, since the trade allegedly found an outlet on different locations. The Sheikhs of the Isaaq have surrendered the assailants implicated in the murder of Stroyan, and the blockade has ended following a treaty that secures our commercial interests.
The Occupation of Karabane and Sédhiou

Karabane and Sédhiou, located on the mouth of the Casamance River, has been claimed by our administration since the 1820s. The commander of our local navy has left for Casamance in search of a suitable site for the future trading post. The village chief of Kagnout has offered us Sédhiou for 196 francs a year, and our navy is starting to build a fort in Karabane to mantain our hold on the region.
Bignona, located north of the mouth of the Casamance River, has been claimed by our administration since the 1810s. We now have an opportunity to occupy Bignona, and we must use it.
The Occupation of the Rio Grande

The River 'Rio Grande' is to the South of Bissau, and is inhabited by non-Papel Bak people. We have tried to occupy it since 300 years ago, but our forts have been destroyed or left to their demise time and time again. With the rest of the European colonial powers starting campaigns around Africa, we should try again and occupy Bolola, founding a new fort in its place.

The Papel Kingdom of Bissau has existed since we started occupying the Guinean Coast, and have been too powerful for us to try to annex them - until now. With the newest technology, we finally have an edge over them, and we can occupy Oio without them burning Bissau to the ground.

The region of Bembe is rich in natural resources, and owned by our ally, the Kingdom of Kongo. Kongo is becoming weaker and weaker with the decadence of the slave trade, and their adaptation to the 'new' trade forcing entire towns to dismantle to turn lands to farming, making their lands unstable. Our settlers in Angola depend upon these natural resources, and we must occupy it to protect our allies in the region.

The region of Bembe is rich in natural resources, and its coast perfect for the construction of a naval base. With our country seeming weak to the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$, they have chosen to occupy this valuable region, and our state has to act, unless we want discontent.

Henrique III Mpanzu a Nsindi a Nimi a Lukeni, our great king, has died today at the age of 59. This afternoon, the electors have chosen Álvaro XIII to rule, but Pedro V has contested the throne. We've expelled Pedro from São Salvador (Mbanza), and he has asked the Portuguese from Bembe for assistance. He has sworn vassalage to Portugal in return, so we can expect a civil war to start.

Henrique III Mpanzu a Nsindi a Nimi a Lukeni, the king of Kongo, has died today at the age of 59. This afternoon, the Kongolese electors have chose Álvaro XIII to rule the kingdom, but Pedro V has contested their throne, and has been expelled from Mbanza. Pedro V has escaped to Ambriz, where he has asked us for support, in exchange of him accepting our vassalage.

Manuel III of Kongo, the current King of Kongo, has been failing to pay his tribute for over a year now. He also has refused to send their army to quell a rebellion to the East, which our local militias have had to engage with, and failed. Today, he has joined the rebellion and called to arms all of his followers in Angola.

Since we've started bordering the Rabih, they have raided our border forts and refused to sign any treaties with us. Some days ago, a rogue column started a military expedition to Togbao, one of their forts, to try and bring them to submission, and even with heavy losses they managed to kill 48 of the 51 $COUNTRY_ADJ$ soldiers. With these casus belli, we have more than sufficient evidence to prove that Rabih must be pacified.

§RGain 2 infamy§! §R(Pay 50,000¤)§! With the European powers encroaching on their territory in multiple fronts, the Southern Azande try to resist occupation. If we fund a big enough expedition, we might be able to make them do otherwise, and sign a protectorate...

The Maasai, Nyamwezi and Ujiji peoples between Zanzibar and Lake Tanganyika are being encroached from the West by colonial expeditions. Their territories have lots of natural resources, and conquering them brinds us the ability to expand more inland, and block the British from obtaining a connection between their colonies.

Yusuf Qaramanli, our great emir, has died today. A civil war has started between the heirs to the throne, as he did not appoint one. The British support one side, and the French the other one. We hope we can quell this rebellion fast, or the Ottomans will come, but not to aid us.

Yusuf Qaramanli, the regent of Tripolitania, has died today. A civil war has started between the heirs to the throne, as he did not appoint one. The British support one side, and the French the other one. The situation at the moment is too unstable for a direct confrontation, and it might just be two or three skirmishes, so waiting could be a good decision.
The Tripolitanian War still rages on, and the European powers are getting preoccupied with their unpaid debts in the region. We must intervene if we don't want the situation to scale further.

Abd al-Jalil, a former Karamanli officer, has taken over our administration and forced our pretender, ibn Ali, to abdicate. He has asked the other pretender to become the king of our state, and for him to be his general.
Abd al-Jalil, a former Karamanli officer, has taken over ibn Ali's administration and forced the traitor to abdicate. He has asked us to become the king of our state, and for him to be our general.

§RGain 2 infamy§! §R(Pay 50,000¤)§! With the European powers encroaching on our former Regency, Algiers, we must find a way to help them resist the invasions and free the Arab world from Christian attacks. Now that we have secured a route for our resources and armies to be sent to Algeria, we can start helping them.
$FROMCOUNTRY$ has proposed an alliance between our states in defence of the French. They will send troops to the region, in exchange of us becoming their protectorate...

$FROMCOUNTRY$ has accepted that we send troops into their territory to defend them. We must now start preparing for a war against the French, as they will most likely not accept our 'encroachment into their internal policies'.

$FROMCOUNTRY$ has rejected our calls for an unified response to the French. They argue that we are who caused the issue in the first place, as in the aftermath of the first war against the French our local garrison raided local towns and had to be expelled.

The Ottomans have started a diplomatic mission to Algiers, supporting the local militias and raiding our local colonies. They are clearly encroaching on our divine right to civilize Algeria, and we must stop them at any cost. We might have to consider another war against the Ottomans, or our colony might fail.

The French have sent us an Ultimatum - stop supporting the 'rebellious Algerine provinces', or face consequences. This is a clear attack towards our move to help Algeria remain independent, and we must act in consequence.
The Ottomans have refused to acknowledge our right to Algeria, and have deemed us 'just another colonialist state'. These insults can only be an invitation to war.

The Libyan Desert has numerous oasis, and has been used for centuries to trade with the Sahel, to the other side of the Sahara. We have influence over most of the oasis in the desert and we might be able to take over their administration, as most of the trade routes there begin in our territory, and the word of Senussi has been heard to the other side of the desert.

The Habr Yunis are a branch of the Isaaq clan, who live in the West of our lands. They have been a vassal of our state for a century, but with the death of our Sultan, Faarax Guuleed, they and other western clans have broken off and put Berbera in siege. They have support from the Emirate of Harar, and will stop the siege if we let them be independent.

The Habr Yunis are a branch of the Isaaq clan, who live in the West of the Isaaq Sultanate. They have been a vassal of the Isaaq for a century, but with the death of their sultan, Faarax Guuleed, they and other western clans have broken off and put Berbera in siege. Isaaq suspects we're supporting them, and have declared war.

Our zawiyas, or monasteries, extend all around the Western Arab World. The ones in the Central Sahara and Libya, though, are becoming more and more economical, educational, and military centers, with buildings teaching tactics, fighting skills and using muskets. We may control parts of the Desert between Tobruk and Waddai, that's not where our influence ends. We could use this to our advantage, and unite the Central Sahara against the foreign powers of the North.

The Senussi have started occupying part of our Southern Territories in spite of our clear prohibition of such act. They seem to ignore our ultimatums, and are fortifying all borders to the North. As we are the only protectors of Algeria, we must send them an Ultimatum.
The French have sent us an Ultimatum - leave what they consider to be the 'Algerian Southern Territories', or face consequences.
The Senussi have refused to give in to our demands, and have continued fortifying their positions. The only way to be heard now is to go to war.

The Senussi are expanding their influence around the Central Sahara, and have asked $FROMCOUNTRY$, who have accepted. They were our vassals, and so they can't just give up their territory to another nation.

The Senussi have asked to administer Tripolitania for us, as they have extreme influence on the region thanks to their zawiyas, or monasteries, which hold economical, educational and military centers. Our local garrison is smaller in number than their militias in our territory, not counting the Senussi's actual army. We might want to give in, or the war could be a humiliation.

Today, the city of Bloemfontein has been founded near Brits' Farm, in the site of a former Barolong Tswana and !Orana Khoekhoe town. The founder is a British Army major named Henry Douglas Warden, who has founded it to fight the !Orana and Barolong resistance to Boer and British rule, and to protect the main route to Winburg.
The Efon have been supporting Oyo in the Jihad, which has undermined our holy war in the region. We should probably launch a Jihad in the region, as their alliance to Benin isn't enough to stop us!

With our recent defeats against rebels in our territory, we've been forced to leave what we thought would be our new homeland. We though have been able to take over Lundazi and successfully create a state in the region.
